ancoralis: <entryFree id="n2502" type="main" key="anco^ra_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŏrālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2502.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to an anchor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">strophia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 265, 7</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŏrāle</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a cable</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 30 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 8, 13, § 34</bibl>; cf. ancorarius.</sense></entryFree>
ancorarius: <entryFree id="n2503" type="hapax" key="anco^ra_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŏrārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2503.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to an anchor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">funes,</quote> <trans><tr>cables</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ancula: <entryFree id="n2504" type="main" key="ancu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> pr. <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>anculus</etym>, <sense id="n2504.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a maidservant</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
anculo: <entryFree id="n2505" type="main" key="ancu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŭlo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, v. anclo.</entryFree>
anculus: <entryFree id="n2506" type="main" key="ancu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> pr. <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>v. 2. Ancus</etym>, <sense id="n2506.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a man-servant</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
ancus: <entryFree id="n2507" type="main" key="ancus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancus</orth> <itype>appellatur, qui aduncum bracchium habet et exporrigi non potest</itype>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=19" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 19</bibl> Müll. [v. ango].</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2508" type="main" key="Ancus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Marcius</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>v. ango</etym> (prop. <sense id="n2508.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a servant</hi>, as bending, crouching; hence = ancus Martius = <foreign lang="greek">qera/pwn *)/arews</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">servant of Mars</hi>), <hi rend="ital">the fourth king of Rome</hi>, A.U.C. 116-140, said to have been the grandson of Numa by Pompilia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:18:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 18, 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:Fragm. p. 241" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> Fragm. p. 241</bibl> Bip.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 32</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:815" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 815</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 7, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:803 al" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 803 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
ancyra: <entryFree id="n2509" type="main" key="Ancy_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancȳra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/agkura</foreign>. <sense id="n2509.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Galatia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Angora</hi>, where was a marble temple of Augustus, built in his lifetime, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:1" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 42, § 146</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> in Eutr. 2, 98</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2509.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Phrygia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 41, § 145</bibl>.—Whence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancȳrānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Ancyra</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> in Eutr. 2, 416</bibl>: Marmor or Monumentum Ancyranum, <hi rend="ital">a Latin inscription on the inside of the antœ of the temple of Augustus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">containing a record of his deeds</hi>, being a copy of the bronze tablets placed in front of his Mausoleum; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:101" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 101</bibl>, and Wolf, <bibl default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> II. p. 369 sq.</bibl>; cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 286.</sense></entryFree>
andabata: <entryFree id="n2510" type="main" key="anda_ba^ta^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andābătă</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2510.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of Roman gladiator</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whose helmet was without openings for the eyes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and who therefore fought blindfolded for the amusement of spectators</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 10</bibl> Manut.: <cit><quote lang="la">more andabatarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> adv. Helv. 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> adv. Jov. 1, 36</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2577</bibl>. <cb n="ANDR" /></sense></entryFree>
andania: <entryFree id="n2511" type="main" key="Andani^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andanĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*andani/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2511.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very ancient town of Messenia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Andorossa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
andes: <entryFree id="n2512" type="main" key="Andes1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andes</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andecāvi</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andicāvi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2512.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Gallic tribe in the region of the present Anjou</hi>, with a town of the same name, now <hi rend="ital">Angors;</hi> form <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andes</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 35</bibl>.—Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andecāvi</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 41</bibl>.—Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andi-cāvi</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 18, 32, § 107</bibl> Jan; cf. Mann. Gall. 163.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2513" type="main" key="Andes2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2513.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a village near Mantua</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the birthplace of Vergil</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Pietola;</hi> hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">from Andes</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Andinus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Vergil</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:595" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 595</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
andinus: <entryFree id="n2514" type="main" key="Andi_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andīnus</orth>, v. 2. Andes.</entryFree>
andrachne: <entryFree id="n2515" type="greek" key="andrachne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrachnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ndra/xnh</foreign>, <sense id="n2515.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">purslane</hi>: Portulacca oleracea, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:10:376" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 10, 376</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 103, § 162</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
andraemon: <entryFree id="n2516" type="main" key="Andraemo_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andraemōn</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)andrai/mwn</foreign>. <sense id="n2516.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The father of Amphissus and husband of Dryope</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who was changed into a lotus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:333" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 333</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 363</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2516.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andraemōn</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrēmon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">father of Thoas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a combatant before Troy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:357" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 357</bibl>; cf. Hom. Il. 2, 638.</sense></entryFree>
andremas: <entryFree id="n2517" type="main" key="andre^mas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrĕmas</orth> = andrachne, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 103</bibl>.</entryFree>
andricus: <entryFree id="n2518" type="main" key="Andri_cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrīcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2518.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a servant of Cicero</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:14:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 14, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
andriscus: <entryFree id="n2519" type="main" key="Andriscus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andriscus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)andri/skos</foreign>, <sense id="n2519.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a slave who claimed to be the son of the Macedonian king Perseus and occasioned the third Macedonian war</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> Epit. 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:11" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:14" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
andrius: <entryFree id="n2520" type="main" key="Andri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n2520.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">born at Andros</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one of the Cyclades</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 3</bibl>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrĭa</orth>, ae. <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a woman of Andros; The Maid of Andros</hi>, a comedy by Terence.</sense></entryFree>
androcles: <entryFree id="n2521" type="main" key="Andro_^cles"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrō^cles</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-clus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)androklh=s</foreign>, <sense id="n2521.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the well-known slave who cured the foot of a lion and was afterwards recognized by the lion and saved from death</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 2:19" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 2, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
androdamas: <entryFree id="n2522" type="greek" key="andro^da^ma_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrŏdămās</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ndroda/mas</foreign> (man-subduing). <sense id="n2522.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A species of bloodstone</hi> (so called from its great hardness), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 20, 38, § 146</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2522.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A silver-colored</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quadrangular</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and cubical precious stone</hi> (acc. to Bruckmann, a cubical, silver-colored marcasite), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 54, § 144</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
androgeon: <entryFree id="n2523" type="main" key="Andro^ge^o_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrŏgĕōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, i. q. Androgeos; <case>acc.</case> Gr. Androgeona, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:1:62" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 1, 62</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrŏgĕōnēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n2523.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to Androgeon</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caedis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 77</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
androgeos: <entryFree id="n2524" type="main" key="Andro^ge^o_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrŏgĕōs</orth>, <itype>ō</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">-gĕus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)andro/gews</foreign>, <sense id="n2524.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">son of the Cretan king Minos</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whom the Athenians and Megarians slew; on account of which the enraged father made war upon them</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:458" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 458</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:10:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 10, 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 20</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
androgyne: <entryFree id="n2525" type="greek" key="andro^gy^ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrŏgynē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ndrogu/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n2525.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a masculine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">heroic woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:8:3:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 8, 3, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
androgynus: <entryFree id="n2526" type="greek" key="andro^gy^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrŏgynus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">-gynē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ndro/gunos, a)ndrogu/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n2526.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a man-woman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hermaphrodite</hi>: imberbus, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 493, 27</bibl>; so * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:43" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 2, 2, § 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:34 al" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 3, 3, § 34 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:839" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 839</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
andromache: <entryFree id="n2527" type="main" key="Andro^ma^che_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrŏmăchē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">-a</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=82" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 82</bibl> Müll., or Trag. v. 100 Vahl.), <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)androma/xh</foreign>, <sense id="n2527.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a daughter of king Eëtion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and wife of Hector.</hi> After the destruction of Troy, she was carried by Pyrrhus to Greece, and was subsequently married to Helenus, son of Priam, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:319" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 319</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 487</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
andromeda: <entryFree id="n2528" type="main" key="Andro^me^da"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrŏmĕda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">-ē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)androme/dh</foreign>, <sense id="n2528.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a daughter of the Ethiopian king Cepheus and Cassiope.</hi> On account of the arrogance of her mother she was bound to a rock by the command of the oracle of Jupiter Ammon, in order that she might be destroyed by a sea-monster; <cit><quote lang="la">but Perseus rescued and married her. After death she was placed as a constellation in heaven,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:671 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 671 sq.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 64" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 64</bibl>; Apollod. 2, 4, 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:43" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:59 al" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 59 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
andron: <entryFree id="n2529" type="greek" key="andro_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ndrw/n</foreign> (<foreign lang="greek">a)nh/r</foreign>, a man). <sense id="n2529.0" n="I" level="1"> Among the Greeks, <hi rend="ital">the part of the house in which the men resided</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the men's apartment;</hi> also called andronitis (opp. gynaeceum, q. v.): locus domicilii, in quo viri <pb n="118" /> <cb n="ANFR" /> morabantur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=19" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 19</bibl> Müll.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 6, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2529.1" n="II" level="1"> Among the Romans, <hi rend="ital">a passage between two walls</hi> or <hi rend="ital">courts of a house</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 6, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
andronicus: <entryFree id="n2530" type="main" key="Andro^ni_cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrŏnīcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2530.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the cognomen of several Romans</hi>, <hi rend="ital">among whom the most distinguished</hi>, L. Livius Andronicus, <hi rend="ital">the first dramatic and epic poet of the Romans</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lived in the middle of the third century</hi> B.C., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:21 al" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 21 al.</bibl>; cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 41 sq.; 78; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 82.</sense></entryFree>
andronitis: <entryFree id="n2531" type="greek" key="andro_ni_tis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrōnītis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ndrwni=tis</foreign>, v. andron, I.</entryFree>
andros: <entryFree id="n2532" type="main" key="Andro^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrŏs</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Andrus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/andros</foreign>, <sense id="n2532.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the largest of the Cyclades</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the Ægean Sea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">south-east of Eubœa</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Andro</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:43 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 43 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:469" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 469</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 649</bibl>; cf. Mann. Greece, p. 743.</sense></entryFree>
androsaces: <entryFree id="n2533" type="greek" key="andro^sa^ce^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrŏsăcĕs</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ndro/sakes</foreign>, <sense id="n2533.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, now unknown, perh. zoophyte, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 4, 9, § 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
androsaemon: <entryFree id="n2534" type="greek" key="andro^saemo^n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andrŏsaemŏn</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ndro/saimon</foreign> (man's blood), <sense id="n2534.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of St. John's-wort</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with blood-red juice</hi>: Hypericum perforatum, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:26 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 4, 10, § 26 sq.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
andruare: <entryFree id="n2535" type="gloss" key="andrua_re"><orth extent="full" lang="la">andruāre</orth>, <sense id="n2535.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to run back</hi>: a Graeco verbo <foreign lang="greek">a)nadramei=n</foreign>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=9" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 9</bibl> Müll.<</sense></entryFree>
aneclogistus: <entryFree id="n2536" type="greek" key="a^neclo^gistus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăneclŏgistus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)neklo/gistos</foreign> (not giving account), <sense id="n2536.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a guardian who was not obliged to give account of his proceedings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but had discretionary power</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:26:7:5:section=7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 26, 7, 5, § 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anellus: <entryFree id="n2537" type="main" key="a_nellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ānellus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">ann-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>anulus</etym>, <sense id="n2537.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little ring</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aureolus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 1, 34</bibl></cit>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:911" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 911</bibl>: cum tribus anellis, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 7, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anemone: <entryFree id="n2538" type="greek" key="a^ne^mo_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĕmōnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nemw/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n2538.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">anemone</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">wind-flower</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 11, 38, § 65</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:164" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 23, 94, § 164</bibl> (in the latter pass. Pliny says it was so called because it opened its flowers only when the wind blew; it grows most abundantly in Alpine districts of warmer regions).</sense></entryFree>
anemurium: <entryFree id="n2539" type="main" key="A^ne^mu_rium"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĕmūrium</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anemou/rion</foreign>, <sense id="n2539.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a promontory and town of Cilicia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Anemūr</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 33, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 27, 22, § 93</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĕmūriensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining</hi> to Anemurium Civitas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 55</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anethum: <entryFree id="n2540" type="greek" key="a^ne_thum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănēthum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/nhqon</foreign>, <sense id="n2540.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dill</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anise</hi>: Anethum graveolens, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 2, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 8, 52, § 167</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:23:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 23, 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aneticus: <entryFree id="n2541" type="greek" key="a^ne^ti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĕtĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)netiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2541.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">remitting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">abating;</hi> of sickness, <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 3, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anfractuosus: <entryFree id="n2542" type="main" key="anfractu^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anfractŭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anfractus</etym>, <sense id="n2542.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">roundabout</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prolix</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">locutio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Serm. 135" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Serm. 135</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anfractus: <entryFree id="n2543" type="main" key="anfractus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anfractus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">amfr-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> <etym>qs. from anfringo</etym>, <sense id="n2543.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">winding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bending</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cooked</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">spatia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 29, 5</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">anfractum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a winding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a crook</hi>, <hi rend="ital">curve</hi> (ante-class. for the class. anfractus, us): terrarum anfracta, Att. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=15" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 15</bibl> Müll. (Trag. Rel. p. 151 Rib.): in anfracto, Varr. ib.: cavata aurium anfracta, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 193, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2544" type="main" key="anfractus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anfractus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">amfr-</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, pr. <sense id="n2544.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a breaking round;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">a bending</hi>, <hi rend="ital">recurving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">turning</hi> (in the ante-class. per. rare; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the preced.</ref></xr> art.). </sense><sense id="n2544.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid pulchrius eā figurā (sc. sphaericā) quae nihil incisum anfractibus, nihil eminens, habere potest?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:18:47" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 18, 47</bibl></cit>.—Hence, of the circular motion of the sun (acc. to the ancient belief): <cit><quote lang="la">solis anfractus,</quote> <trans><tr>a circuit</tr>, <tr>revolution</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 12</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 8</bibl>.—Of the crookedness of horns: <cit><quote lang="la">cornua convoluta in anfractum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 45, § 124</bibl></cit>.—Of the coils of a serpent, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:7:523" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 7, 523</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:520" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 520</bibl>.—Also freq., particularly in the histt., of the turning or winding of a road, etc., <hi rend="ital">a tortuous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">circuitous route</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si nullus anfractus intercederet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illa (via) altero tanto longiorem habebat anfractum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:8:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 8, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per anfractus jugi procurrere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anfractus viarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 33, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">litorum anfractus,</quote> <trans><tr>the windings</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:7 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 38, 7 al.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:605" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 605</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n2544.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of discourse, = ambages, <hi rend="ital">circumlocution</hi>, <hi rend="ital">digression</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid opus est circuitione et anfractu?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:61:127" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 61, 127</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratio circumscripta non longo anfractu, sed ad spiritum vocis apto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:6:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Part. Or. 6, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae omnia infinitus anfractus habent,</quote> <trans><tr>ramifications</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 1, 15</bibl></cit>, where Bonn. and Halm read <hi rend="ital">tractatus.</hi>—Of legal matters, <hi rend="ital">intricacies</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prolixity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">judiciorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:56:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 56, 159</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:9:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 9, 3</bibl></cit>. <cb n="ANGO" /></sense></entryFree>
angaria: <entryFree id="n2545" type="main" key="anga^ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angărĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ggari/a</foreign> [angarius], <sense id="n2545.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the service of the</hi> angarius, and, in gen., <hi rend="ital">service to a lord</hi>, <hi rend="ital">villanage</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:4:18:section=29" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 4, 18, § 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:5:11 al" default="NO">50, 5, 11 al.</bibl>; v. on angaria and angarialis, Gloss. Man. art. clabularis.</sense></entryFree>
angarialis: <entryFree id="n2546" type="hapax" key="anga^ri^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angărĭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>angaria</etym>, <sense id="n2546.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to service</hi>: copia, Cod. Th. 8, 5, 4.</sense></entryFree>
angario: <entryFree id="n2547" type="main" key="anga^ri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angărĭo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n2547.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to demand something as</hi> angaria, <hi rend="ital">to exact villanage</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:49:18:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 49, 18, 4</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 5" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 5 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl> al. —</sense><sense id="n2547.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to compel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">constrain</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">quicumque te angariaverit mille passus (vadere), vade cum illo et alia duo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 5, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc angariaverunt, ut tollant crucem ejus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 27, 32</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:15:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 15, 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angaris: <entryFree id="n2548" type="main" key="Anga^ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Angăris</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2548.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain in Palestine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 13, 14, § 68</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angarius: <entryFree id="n2549" type="hapax" key="anga^ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angărĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/ggaros</foreign> [introd. into the Greek from the Persian], <sense id="n2549.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a messenger</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a courier</hi>, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 21, 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angea: <entryFree id="n2550" type="main" key="Ange^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Angĕa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2550.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Thessaly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angelicus: <entryFree id="n2551" type="greek" key="ange^li^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angĕlĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ggeliko/s</foreign> (suitable or pertaining to messengers). <sense id="n2551.0" n="I" level="1"> Angelicum metrum, <hi rend="ital">a dactylic measure</hi> (so called on account of its rapidity of movement), <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 512</bibl> P.; Victor. p. 2531 P. —</sense><sense id="n2551.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Belonging to angels</hi>, <hi rend="ital">angelic</hi>: habens vultum angelicum, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:13:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jud. 13, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">panes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Tetr. 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
angelificatus: <entryFree id="n2552" type="hapax" key="ange^li^fi^ca_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angĕlĭfĭcātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, qs. <sense id="n2552.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">part.</hi> of angelifico, <hi rend="ital">changed into an angel</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caro,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Res. Carn. 25</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
angellus: <entryFree id="n2553" type="main" key="angellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angellus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>angulus</etym>, <sense id="n2553.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little angle</hi> or <hi rend="ital">corner</hi> (only ante- and post-class.), * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:428" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 428</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 7, p. 253</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angelus: <entryFree id="n2554" type="greek" key="ange^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angĕlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/ggelos</foreign>. <sense id="n2554.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A messenger</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 20" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 20 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl> dub.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:11:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 11, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2554.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An angel.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2554.2" n="A" level="2"> In bon. part. very freq. in the Vulg., the Church fathers, Aug., Tertull., Jerome, etc.—</sense><sense id="n2554.3" n="B" level="2"> In mal. part.: <cit><quote lang="la">Diabolus et angeli ejus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:25:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 25, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angelus Satanae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:12:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Cor. 12, 7</bibl></cit> al.</sense></entryFree>
angerona: <entryFree id="n2555" type="main" key="Ange^ro_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Angĕrōna</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">-ia</orth>, Macr.), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>ango</etym>, <sense id="n2555.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the goddess of Suffering and Silence</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 65</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 116</bibl>. —Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Angĕrōnālĭa</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">her festival</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=23" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 23</bibl> Müll.; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=17" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 17</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
angina: <entryFree id="n2556" type="main" key="angi^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angĭna</orth> (for the quantity of the pen., <sense id="n2556.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the foll.</ref></xr> examples, and cf. Wagner ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 139</bibl>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)gxo/nh</foreign>; v. ango</etym>. </sense><sense id="n2556.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The quinsy</hi>, as suffocating: Insperato abiit quam unā angina sustulit horā, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 35, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sues moriuntur angĭnā acri acerrume,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 139</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Angĭna verŏ sibi mixtum sale poscit acetum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ser. Samm.</author> 282</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:61 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 2, 29, § 61 al.</bibl>: anginam vinariam habere dicuntur, qui vino suffocantur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n2556.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">angina mentis,</quote> <trans><tr>distress of mind</tr>, <tr>produced by physical disease</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 48</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
angiportus: <entryFree id="n2557" type="main" key="angi^portus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angĭportus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (and <orth extent="full" lang="la">angĭpor-tum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 714</bibl> P.) [ang- as in angustus, and portus; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=145" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 145</bibl> Müll.; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=17" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 17</bibl> Müll.], <sense id="n2557.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a narrow street</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lane</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">alley</hi>, Paul. ex Fest. l. l.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:16:59" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 16, 59</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 2, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 5, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">viae omnes angiportusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:32:69" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 32, 69</bibl></cit>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:25:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 25, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 2, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 7, 137</bibl>; id. Cist. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 190, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 2, 6</bibl>: angiporto toto deerrare, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 51, 64</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quadriviis et angiportis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:58:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 58, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
angitia: <entryFree id="n2558" type="main" key="Angi^ti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Angĭtĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2558.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sister of Medea and Circe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who received divine honors from the Marsi</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:759" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 759</bibl> (acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 7, 750</bibl>, <hi rend="ital">Medea herself</hi>); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:498" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 498</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 115</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">116</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1846</bibl>.—Hence, Nemus Angitiae, <hi rend="ital">the region consecrated to Angitia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near Lucus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the Marsian territory</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Luco</hi>, Verg. l. c.; cf. Mann. Ital. 1, 515.</sense></entryFree>
angli: <entryFree id="n2559" type="main" key="Angli"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Angli</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2559.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Angli</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a branch of the Suevi in Lower Germany</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 40</bibl>; c. A.D. 450 they united with the Saxons (hence the designation <hi rend="ital">Anglo-Saxons</hi>), conquered Britannia, and gave their name to the country,—Anglia, <hi rend="ital">England.</hi></sense></entryFree>
anglia: <entryFree id="n2560" type="main" key="Angli^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anglĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. Angli.</entryFree>
ango: <entryFree id="n2561" type="main" key="ango"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ango</orth>, <itype>xi, ctum, and anxum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (<sense id="n2561.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi> rest only on the assertion in <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 895</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 366</bibl> P.; <hi rend="ital">part.</hi> anctus, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=24" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 24</bibl> Müll.; acc. to <cb n="ANGU" /> Prisc. l. c., the <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi> is sometimes anxum; cf. Struve, 214) [the root of this word is widely diffused: <foreign lang="greek">a)/gkos</foreign>, a bend, hollow; whence, valley, ravine; from the notion of <hi rend="ital">closeness</hi>, come <foreign lang="greek">a)/gxw</foreign> = to press tight, to strangle, throttle; ango; Germ. hangen, hängen; Engl. hang; angustus, anxius, anxietas; old Germ. Angust; Germ. Angst = Engl. anguish; from the notion of <hi rend="ital">being bent</hi>, come ancus anculus, a crouching slave, ancora = Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)/gkura</foreign>; angulus = Germ. Angel, Engl. angle; old Germ. Angul, a hook; Gael. ingle = nook for the fire, fireplace; ancale = <foreign lang="greek">a)gka/lh</foreign>, Engl. ankle; ancon, and the pr. names Ancon and Ancona; uncus, curved, crooked; ungula, claw; unguis, claw, nail; cf. Sanscr. ahus, close; ahas, anguish; ankāmi, to bend; ankas, the lap (sinus), a hook; for the other Greek words belonging to this group, v. L. and S. s. vv. <foreign lang="greek">a)/gkos</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">a)/gxw</foreign>]. </sense><sense id="n2561.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to bind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">draw</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">press together;</hi> of the throat, <hi rend="ital">to throttle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strangle</hi> (so <foreign lang="greek">a)/gxw</foreign>; in this signif. antiquated; hence, in class. perh. only in the poets; in prose, instead of it, suffocare; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 361</bibl> P.): <cit><quote lang="la">angit inhaerens Elisos oculos et siccum sanguine guttur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:260" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 260</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:497" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 3, 497</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum colla minantia monstri Angeret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:828" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 828</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 270</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:584" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 584</bibl>.—Hence, of plants, <hi rend="ital">to choke</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:2:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:27:7 al" default="NO">6, 27, 7 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2561.2" n="II" level="1"> Metaph. </sense><sense id="n2561.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To cause</hi> (physical) <hi rend="ital">pain;</hi> hence, angi, <hi rend="ital">to feel</hi> or <hi rend="ital">suffer pain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 60, 79, § 164</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n2561.4" n="B" level="2"> Most freq. of the mind, <hi rend="ital">to distress</hi>, <hi rend="ital">torment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">torture</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vex</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trouble;</hi> and angi, <hi rend="ital">to feel distressed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to suffer torment</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">illum incommodis dictis angam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: cura angit hominem, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 3, 8</bibl>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1134</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cruciatu timoris angi?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:7:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 7, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multa sunt, quae me sollicitant anguntque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angebar singularum horarum exspectatio ne,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 1</bibl></cit> et saep.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 1 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne munere te parvo beet aut incommodus angat (cruciet, cum non vult dare quod poscis, Cruqu.),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 18, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad humum maerore gravi deducit et angit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. P. 110</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">poëta, meum qui pectus inaniter angit,</quote> <trans><tr>puts in torturing suspense</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 211 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pompeius ... curis animum mordacibus angit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:2:680 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 2, 680 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ea res animum illius anxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(aemula eam) vehementer angebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 1, 6</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">de</hi> (in respect to): <cit><quote lang="la">de Statio manumisso et non nullis aliis rebus angor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de quo angor et crucior,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 22</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> (on this const. cf. Roby, II. § <cit><quote lang="la">1321): absurde facis, qui angas te animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Sthenius) angebatur animi necessario, quod etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:34:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 34, 84</bibl></cit>. But Cic. also uses the <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">angor animo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Brut.</author> 2, 7</bibl></cit>: audio te animo angi, Fam. 16, 142; and acc. to some edd. Tusc. 1, 40, 96 Seyff. (v. further on this <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> s. v. animus).</sense></entryFree>
angor: <entryFree id="n2562" type="main" key="angor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ango</etym>, = angina. <sense id="n2562.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A compression of the neck</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a strangling</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">occupat fauces earum angor,</quote> <trans><tr>the quinsy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 27, 41, § 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestu et angore vexata, i.e. aestu angorem ac prope suffocationem efficiente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 48</bibl></cit>.—Far oftener, </sense><sense id="n2562.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">anguish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">torment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trouble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vexation</hi> (as a momentary feeling; while <hi rend="ital">anxietas</hi> denotes a permanent state): est aliud iracundum esse, aliud iratum, ut differt anxietas ab angore; neque enim omnes anxii, qui anguntur aliquando; <cit><quote lang="la">nec qui anxii, semper anguntur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:12:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 12, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angor est aegritudo premens,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 8, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:853" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 853</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxius angor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:993" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 993</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 1158</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus omni liber curā et angore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:15:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 15, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angor pro amico saepe capiendus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:13:48" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Am. 13, 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">angor animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 7</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 49</bibl> al.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">confici angoribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 1, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angrivarii: <entryFree id="n2563" type="main" key="Angrivarii"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Angrivarii</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2563.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a German tribe in the neighborhood of the Teutoburg Forest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on both sides of the Weser</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 33</bibl> Rup.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 19</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 22</bibl>; 2, 24; 2, 41.</sense></entryFree>
anguen: <entryFree id="n2564" type="main" key="anguen"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguen</orth>, v. anguis <sense id="n2564.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
angueus: <entryFree id="n2565" type="hapax" key="angue^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anguis</etym>, <sense id="n2565.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to a serpent</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lapsus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 24</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anguicomus: <entryFree id="n2566" type="main" key="angui^co^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĭcŏmus</orth> (four syl.), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anguis-coma</etym>, <sense id="n2566.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">with snaky hair</hi> (only in the poets): <cit><quote lang="la">Gorgon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:699" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 699</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:4:801" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 801</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:544" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 544</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anguiculus: <entryFree id="n2567" type="hapax" key="angui^cu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĭcŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>anguis</etym>, <sense id="n2567.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small serpent</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:15:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 15, 42</bibl>. <pb n="119" /> <cb n="ANGU" /></sense></entryFree>
anguifer: <entryFree id="n2568" type="main" key="angui^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĭfer</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>fĕra, fĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anguis-fero</etym>, <sense id="n2568.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">serpent-bearing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:741" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 741</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Gorgo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:2:8" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 2, 8</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Anguĭfer</orth>, <itype>fĕri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (as transl. of <foreign lang="greek">*)ofiou=xos</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">the serpent-bearer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the constellation Serpentarius</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Ophiuchus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:49" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 49</bibl>; cf. anguitenens.</sense></entryFree>
anguigena: <entryFree id="n2569" type="hapax" key="angui^ge^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĭgĕna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>anguis-gigno</etym>, <sense id="n2569.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">engendered of a snake</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dragon</hi>, an epithet of the Thebans, who sprang from dragons' teeth, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:531" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 531</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">draconigena urbs,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Thebes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:865" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 3, 865</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anguilla: <entryFree id="n2570" type="main" key="anguilla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguilla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>anguis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=77" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 77</bibl> Müll.; but it may be directly con. with Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)/gxelus</foreign>; v. anguis</etym>, <sense id="n2570.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an eel.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2570.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: Muraena anguilla, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:74 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 21, 38, § 74 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:5:103" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 5, 103</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2570.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: anguilla est, elabitur, <hi rend="ital">he is an eel; he slips away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is a slippery fellow</hi>, prov. of a sly man, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:4:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 2, 4, 56</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2570.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The hard skin of an eel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">used as a whip in schools</hi>, Verr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:23:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 23, 39</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 5, 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anguimanus: <entryFree id="n2571" type="main" key="angui^ma^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĭ-mănus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anguismanus</etym>, <sense id="n2571.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">with serpent-hand</hi>, an epithet of the elephant, because he makes quick, serpent-like motions with his trunk (manus), perh. only in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:537" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 537</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1303" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 1303</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anguineus: <entryFree id="n2572" type="main" key="angui^ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĭnĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anguis</etym>, less freq. than the foll. <sense id="n2572.0" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the serpent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">snaky</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Gorgonis comae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:7:12" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 7, 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2572.1" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Similar to a serpent in form</hi>, <hi rend="ital">serpent-like</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cucumis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:9:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 9, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:10:5" default="NO">7, 10, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anguinus: <entryFree id="n2573" type="main" key="angui_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2573.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the serpent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">snaky</hi>: cervix, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:64" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 64</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">capillus Eumenidum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:193" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 193</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pellis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cucumis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:2:25" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adeps,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 30, 5, 12, § 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vernatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 3, 8, § 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:23 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 3, 8, § 23 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">anguīnum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. ovum), <hi rend="ital">a snake's egg</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 3, 12, § 52</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anguipes: <entryFree id="n2574" type="hapax" key="angui^pe_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĭ-pēs</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕdis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anguis-pes</etym>, <sense id="n2574.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">serpent - footed</hi>, an epithet of giants, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:184" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 184</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">serpentipedes Gigantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:7:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 4, 7, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anguis: <entryFree id="n2575" type="main" key="anguis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguis</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">dissyl.</orth>), <itype>is</itype> (rare form <orth extent="full" lang="la">an-guen</orth>, <itype>like sanguen for sanguis</itype>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1672,001:Rer. Gest. Alex. M. 1:29" default="NO"><author>Jul. Val.</author> Rer. Gest. Alex. M. 1, 29</bibl> Mai.—<sense id="n2575.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Abl.</hi> angue; but angui, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 28</bibl>, or Trag. v. 51 Vahl.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 17, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:483" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 483</bibl> MS.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 766</bibl> P.; in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:31:66" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 31, 66</bibl>, suspected by Schne<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gram. II. 227</bibl>, on account of angue just before; angue also, Enn. ap. Acron. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:11:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 11, 18</bibl>, or Trag. v. 441 Vahl.; Varr. Atac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 70</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:30:65" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 30, 65</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:4:40" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 4, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:9:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 9, 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 3, 6, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:349" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 10, 349</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">15, 390</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Fur. 793" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Fur. 793</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:85" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 85</bibl>; cf. Neue, Formenl. I. p. 218), <gen>m.</gen> and <gen>f.</gen>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 70</bibl> P.; Rudd. I. p. 25; Neue, Formenl. I. p. 612 [cf. <foreign lang="greek">e)/gxelus</foreign>; Lith. angis; old Germ. unc = adder; <foreign lang="greek">e)/xis; e)/xidna</foreign> = adder; Sanscr. ahis; Germ. Aal = Engl. eel. Curtius], <hi rend="ital">a serpent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a snake</hi> (syn.: serpens, coluber, draco). </sense><sense id="n2575.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: angues jugati, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 191, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:1:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 5, 1, 56</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">emissio feminae anguis ... maris anguis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vertatur Cadmus in anguem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:187 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 187 al.</bibl></cit>—As <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: caerulea, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">angues volucres vento invectae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 36</bibl></cit>: torta, Varr. Atac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 191, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:11 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 11 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Masc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">domi vectem circumjectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ater,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:5:40" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 5, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tortus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:483" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 483</bibl></cit>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:4:79" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ib. 4, 79</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:485" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 485</bibl>.—Sometimes <hi rend="ital">serpent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">snake</hi>, as a hateful, odious object: <cit><quote lang="la">odisse aliquem aeque atque angues,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:4:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 4, 4, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cane pejus et angui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 17, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2575.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2575.3" n="A" level="2"> In fable, an emblem. </sense><sense id="n2575.4" n="1" level="3"> Of terror; <cit><quote lang="la">hence the snaky head of Medusa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:803" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 803</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2575.5" n="2" level="3"> Of rage; <cit><quote lang="la">hence the serpent-girdle of Tisiphone,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:483" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 483</bibl></cit> and 511; <cit><quote lang="la">her hair of snakes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:3:69" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 3, 69</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:5:40" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 5, 40</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2575.6" n="3" level="3"> Of art and wisdom; <cit><quote lang="la">hence the serpent-team of Medea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:223" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 223</bibl></cit>, and of the inventive Ceres, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:642" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 642</bibl>; cf. Voss, Mythol. Br. 2, 55.—</sense><sense id="n2575.7" n="B" level="2"> As a constellation. </sense><sense id="n2575.8" n="1" level="3"> = draco, <hi rend="ital">the Dragon</hi>, between the Great and the Little Bear, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Astr. 2:3" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Astr. 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:3:2" default="NO">3, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">flexu sinuoso elabitur Anguis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:244" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 244</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neu te tortum declinet ad Anguem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:138" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 138</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2575.9" n="2" level="3"> = hydra, <hi rend="ital">the Hydra</hi>, <hi rend="ital">water-serpent</hi>, which extends over the constellations Cancer, Leo, and Virgo, carries on its back the Crater, and on its tail the Corvus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:243" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 243</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 1, 422</bibl>; <cb n="ANGU" /> cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Astr. 3:39" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Astr. 3, 39</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2575.10" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The Serpent</hi>, which Anguitenens (<foreign lang="greek">*)ofiou=xos</foreign>) carries in his hand, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 182</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2575.11" n="C" level="2"> Prov.: Latet anguis in herbā, <hi rend="ital">there's a snake in the grass</hi>, of some concealed danger, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 3, 93</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anguitenens: <entryFree id="n2576" type="main" key="angui^te^nens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anguĭ-tĕnens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anguis-teneo</etym>, <sense id="n2576.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">serpent-holding;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the constellation</hi>, = anguifer, transl. of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*)ofiou=xos</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Serpent-bearer</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 42</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 5, 384</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angularis: <entryFree id="n2577" type="main" key="angu^la_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angŭlāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>angulus</etym>, <sense id="n2577.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">having corners</hi> or <hi rend="ital">angles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">angular</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lapis,</quote> <trans><tr>a square stone</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 14, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:3:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 3, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lapis,</quote> <trans><tr>a corner-stone</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 38, 6</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and, in trop. sense,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:28:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Isa. 28, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Ephes. 2, 20</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1</bibl> Pet. 2, 6: <cit><quote lang="la">pilae,</quote> <trans><tr>corner pillars of an arcade</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 11</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">angŭlā-ris</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an angular vessel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:5:3 al" default="NO"><author>Apic.</author> 5, 3 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
angulatim: <entryFree id="n2578" type="main" key="angu^la_tim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angŭlātim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2578.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">from corner to corner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from angle to angle</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">cuncta perlustrari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 237, 26</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3</bibl>, p. 103; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 7, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angulo: <entryFree id="n2579" type="main" key="angu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angŭlo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2579.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make angular</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cornered</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> Ep. 42</bibl>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">angŭlātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">made angular; with angles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">angular</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpuscula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 24</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
angulosus: <entryFree id="n2580" type="main" key="angu^lo_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angŭlōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2580.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of corners</hi> (post-Aug.; <cit><quote lang="la">perh. only in Plin.): folia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 23, 35, § 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 15, 24, 29, § 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">recessus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 4, 5, § 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gemmae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 12, 75, § 196</bibl></cit> et saep.</sense></entryFree>
angulus: <entryFree id="n2581" type="main" key="angu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>cf. <foreign lang="greek">a)gku/los</foreign>, crooked, bent, angular, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=11" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 11</bibl> Müll.; v. ango</etym>, <sense id="n2581.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an angle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a corner.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2581.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2581.2" n="A" level="2"> Math. t. t., <hi rend="ital">an angle</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">angulus optusus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:355" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 355</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angulus acutus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 3, 29, § 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meridianus circulus horizonta rectis angulis secat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 5:17" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 5, 17</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">ad pares angulos ad terram ferri,</quote> <trans><tr>at right angles</tr>, <tr>perpendicularly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:17:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 17, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hoc ubi suffugit sensum simul angulus omnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:360" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 360</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">figura, quae nihil habet incisum angulis, nihil anfractibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 18</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2581.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A corner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hujus lateris alter angulus qui est ad Cantium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">extremus,</quote> <trans><tr>the extreme point</tr>, <tr>corner</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:884" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 884</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 6, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:178" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 66, § 178</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">arcae anguli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:25:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 25, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quattuor anguli pallii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:22:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Deut. 22, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic factus est in caput anguli,</quote> <trans><tr>the corner-stone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:21:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 21, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anguli oculorum,</quote> <trans><tr>the corners of the eyes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:6:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 6, 6, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 14, 77, § 126</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anguli parietum,</quote> <trans><tr>the angles of walls</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 82, 84, § 197</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">murorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,016:26:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Par. 26, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in angulis platearum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 6, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quattuor anguli terrae,</quote> <trans><tr>the four quarters of the earth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 7, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2581.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2581.5" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A retired</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfrequented place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a nook</hi>, <hi rend="ital">corner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lurking-place</hi>: in angulum abire, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 2, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemo non modo Romae, sed nec ullo in angulo totius Italiae oppressus aere alieno fuit, quem etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille terrarum mihi praeter omnes Angulus ridet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 6, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angulus hic mundi nunc me accipit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:9:65" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 9, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gratus puellae risus ab angulo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:9:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 9, 22</bibl></cit>;
