<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:102:3" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 102, 3</bibl>.—Contemptuously, of the schools or places of private discussion, in contrast with public, practical life: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus ego, ut de his rebus in angulis consumendi otii causā disserant, cum concessero, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:13:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 13, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">earum ipsarum rerum, quas isti in angulis personant, reapse, non oratione perfectio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 3, 16</bibl>.—On the contr. without contempt, in Seneca, Ep. 95.—So also, detractingly, of a little country-seat, in opp. to the city: quod Angulus iste feret piper, <hi rend="ital">that hole</hi>, said by the discontented steward, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 14, 23</bibl> (so without detraction: <cit><quote lang="la">recessus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:230" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 230</bibl></cit>).—* <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: me ex hoc, ut ita dicam, campo aequitatis ad istas verborum angustias et ad omnes litterarum angulos revocas, <hi rend="ital">into every strait</hi>, <hi rend="ital">embarrassment</hi> (the figure is taken from a contest or game, in which one strives to get his antagonist into a corner), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 29</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2581.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A projection of the sea into the land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a bay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gulf</hi>: Gallicus, Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 185</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
anguste: <entryFree id="n2582" type="main" key="anguste_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angustē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v angustus <sense id="n2582.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
angustiae: <entryFree id="n2583" type="main" key="angusti^ae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angustĭae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype> (rare in class. Lat. in <sense id="n2583.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sing</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">angustĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 6, 8, § 61</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 20</bibl> P.; <cit><quote lang="la">but freq. in eccl. Lat.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:42:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 42, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:118:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Psa. 118, 143</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Cor. 2, 4</bibl> al.), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>angustus</etym>. </sense><sense id="n2583.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">narrowness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">straitness; a defile</hi>, <cb n="ANGU" /> <hi rend="ital">strait</hi> (perhaps only in prose; syn.: fauces, angustum). </sense><sense id="n2583.2" n="A" level="2"> Of places: <cit><quote lang="la">Corinthus posita in angustiis atque in faucibus Graeciae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 32</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:20:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 20, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">itineris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 39</bibl></cit>: Italia coacta in angustias, Sall. Fragm. H. ap. Serv ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:400" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 400</bibl> (97, II. p. 250 Gerl.): <cit><quote lang="la">loci,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> C. 58, 20</bibl></cit>: quod intercidit et incuriā coloni locique angustiā. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 6, 8, § 61</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">angustiae locorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 8, 4</bibl></cit>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:12:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 12, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">angustiae saltibus crebris inclusae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diu in angustiis pugnatum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">itinerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 43 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per angustias Hellesponti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:63" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vicorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 38</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:9 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oth. 9 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2583.3" n="B" level="2"> Of other things: <cit><quote lang="la">spiritūs,</quote> <trans><tr>shortness of breath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:46:181" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 46, 181</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urinae,</quote> <trans><tr>strangury</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 21, 92, § 160</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2583.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2583.5" n="A" level="2"> Of time, <hi rend="ital">shortness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brevity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">want</hi>, <hi rend="ital">deficiency</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in his vel asperitatibus rerum vel angustiis temporis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1</bibl></cit>. 1: <cit><quote lang="la">edidi quae potui, non ut volui, sed ut me temporis angustiae coëgerunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 56</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fil. ad Tir. Fam. 16, 21, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in angustiā temporum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:9:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Dan. 9, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2583.6" n="B" level="2"> Of money or other possessions, <hi rend="ital">scarcity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">want</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aerarii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniae publicae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 12, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rei frumentariae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortunae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stipendii,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad eas rei familiaris angustias decidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:9" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 9</bibl></cit>.— Sometimes <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">want</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indigence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">poverty</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex meis angustiis illius sustento tenuitatem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fil. ad Tir. Fam. 16, 21, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paternae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 75</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2583.7" n="C" level="2"> Of external circumstances, condition, etc., <hi rend="ital">difficulty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">distress</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perplexity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">straits</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in summas angustias adduci,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 5</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:9:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 9, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum in his angustiis res esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vereri angustias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angustiae petitionis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the difficulty of obtaining the consular dignity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=47" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 47</bibl></cit>. —So the Vulg. very freq. of external circumstances and of inward state, both in <number>sing.</number> and in <number>plur.</number>: videntes angustiam animi, Gen. 42, 21; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Exod. 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 2, 9</bibl>; and <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2 Cor. 2, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tenent me angustiae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2 Reg. 1, 9</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2 Cor. 6, 4</bibl>; 12, 10 al. —</sense><sense id="n2583.8" n="D" level="2"> Of mind or feeling, <hi rend="ital">narrowness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contractedness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non capiunt angustiae pectoris tui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 11</bibl></cit>: cujus animus tantis angustiis invidiae continetur, <hi rend="ital">by such meanness of envy</hi>, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 43</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2583.9" n="E" level="2"> Of scientific inquiries which go too deeply into details, and lay too much stress upon little things, <hi rend="ital">subtile</hi> or <hi rend="ital">minute verbal criticisms</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">me ex campo aequitatis ad istas verborum angustias revocas,</quote> <trans><tr>into a dilemma of verbal subtleties</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cur eam (orationem) in tantas angustias et in Stoicorum dumeta compellimus?</quote> <trans><tr>straits</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2583.10" n="F" level="1"> Of discourse, <hi rend="ital">brevity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">simplicity</hi>: angustia conclusae orationis non facile se ipsa tutatur. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:7:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 7, 20</bibl> (v. the context).—So in <number>sing.</number>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 73, 26</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angusticlavius: <entryFree id="n2584" type="hapax" key="angusti^cla_vi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angustĭclāvĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>angustus-clavus</etym>, <sense id="n2584.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wearing a narrow</hi> (<hi rend="ital">purple</hi>) <hi rend="ital">stripe;</hi> an epithet of a plebeian tribune, who, as a plebeian, could wear only a narrow stripe of purple on his tunic (while the tribune from the nobility had a broad stripe, v. laticlavius), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angustio: <entryFree id="n2585" type="main" key="angusti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angustĭo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>angustus</etym>, pr. <sense id="n2585.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make narrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to straiten;</hi> only trop. and in eccl. Lat. <hi rend="ital">to straiten</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hamper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">distress</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">angustiatus prae pavore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:13:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jud. 13, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui se angustiaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,033:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Sap. 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed non angustiamur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Cor. 4, 8</bibl></cit>; 6, 12; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:11:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Heb. 11, 37</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
angustitas: <entryFree id="n2586" type="main" key="angusti^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angustĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = angustia, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 73, 25</bibl>.</entryFree>
angusto: <entryFree id="n2587" type="main" key="angusto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angusto</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>angustus</etym>, <sense id="n2587.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make narrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to straiten</hi> (first used after the Aug. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">Cujus (Hellesponti) iter caesis angustans corporum acervis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:359" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 359</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(puteus) ore angustatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 8, 4, § 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">servorum turba, quae quamvis magnam domum angustet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Cons. ad Helv. 11" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Cons. ad Helv. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">maris angustat fauces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:232" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 232</bibl></cit>: angustare aëris meatus. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:327" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 327</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animam in artus tumidos angustare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:827" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 827</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">12, 665</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to circumscribe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">restrain</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gaudia sua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Cons. ad Polyb. 29" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Cons. ad Polyb. 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angustanda sunt patrimonia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Tranq. 8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tranq. 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
angustus: <entryFree id="n2588" type="main" key="angustus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">angustus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um. <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>v. ango</etym>, <sense id="n2588.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">narrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strait</hi>, esp. of local relations, <hi rend="ital">close</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contracted</hi>, <hi rend="ital">small</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not spacious</hi> (syn.: artus, brevis, contractus; <cit><quote lang="la">opp. latus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 29, 92</bibl></cit>). <pb n="120" /> <cb n="ANGU" /> </sense><sense id="n2588.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">fretus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:720" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 720</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Angustum per iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 1132</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 92:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 92, 7</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Judith, 4, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pontes angusti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 3, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:20:65" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 20, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fauces portūs angustissimae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 1, 2</bibl></cit> Herz.: <cit><quote lang="la">cellae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 8, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rima,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Principis angustā Caprearum in rupe sedentis,</quote> <trans><tr>on the narrow rock</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:93" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 93</bibl></cit> Herm., where Jahn reads <hi rend="ital">augusta</hi>, both readings yielding an apposite sense: <cit><quote lang="la">porta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 7, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:13:24 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 13, 24 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">angustum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">narrowness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per angustum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:530" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 530</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angusta viarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:332" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 332</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pontes et viarum angusta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2588.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2588.3" n="A" level="2"> In angustum concludere, adducere, deducere, etc., <hi rend="ital">to reduce to a strait</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to restrain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">confine</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">ab illā immensā societate humani generis in exiguum angustumque concluditur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicitia ex infinitā societate generis humani ita contracta est et adducta in angustum, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Am. 5</bibl></cit>.—Of the passions, <hi rend="ital">to curb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">restrain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moderate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">perturbationes animi contrahere et in angustum deducere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2588.4" n="B" level="2"> Of other things: clavus angustus, <hi rend="ital">the narrow purple stripe upon the tunic</hi>, v. clavus: <cit><quote lang="la">spiritus,</quote> <trans><tr>short</tr>, <tr>difficult</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">odor rosae,</quote> <trans><tr>not diffused far</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 4, 10, § 14</bibl></cit>.—Once also of the point of an arrow = acutus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 7, 5</bibl>, n. 2.— </sense><sense id="n2588.5" n="C" level="2"> Of time, <hi rend="ital">short</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brief</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">angustus dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:10:8" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 10, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:442" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 442</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nox,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:7:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 7, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:447" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 4, 447</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2588.6" n="D" level="2"> Of means of living, and the like, <hi rend="ital">pinching</hi>, <hi rend="ital">scanty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">needy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pauperies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res angusta domi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:164" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 164</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Thyest. 452" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Thyest. 452</bibl></cit>: domus, <hi rend="ital">poor</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">built without much expense</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 33</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2588.7" n="E" level="2"> Of other external relations of life, <hi rend="ital">difficult</hi>, <hi rend="ital">critical</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uncertain</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rebus angustis animosus atque Fortis adpare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:10:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 10, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum fides totā Italiā esset angustior,</quote> <trans><tr>was weakened</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 1</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">angustum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a difficult</hi>, <hi rend="ital">critical</hi>, <hi rend="ital">condition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">danger</hi>: in angustum cogi, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 2, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">res est in angusto,</quote> <trans><tr>the condition is perilous</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes est in angusto,</quote> <trans><tr>hope is feeble</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 8, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2588.8" n="F" level="1"> Of mind or character, <hi rend="ital">narrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">base</hi>, <hi rend="ital">low</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mean-spirited</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil est tam angusti animi, tam parvi, quam amare divitias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:20:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 20, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animi angusti et demissi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:24:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 24, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ecce autem alii minuti et angusti, aut omnia semper desperantes, aut malevoli, invidi, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:18:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 18, 61</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2588.9" n="G" level="1"> Of learned investigations that lay too much stress upon little things, <hi rend="ital">subtle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hair-splitting</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">minutae angustaeque concertationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pungunt (Stoici) quasi aculeis, interrogatiunculis angustis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:3:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 3, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2588.10" n="H" level="1"> Of discourse, <hi rend="ital">brief</hi>, <hi rend="ital">simple</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">et angusta quaedam et concisa, et alia est dilatata et fusa oratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:56:187" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 56, 187</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Intonet angusto pectore Callimachus,</quote> <trans>i.e. <tr>in simple style</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:1:40" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 1, 40</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">angustē</orth>. </sense><sense id="n2588.11" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of space, quantity, or number, <hi rend="ital">within narrow limits</hi>, <hi rend="ital">closely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hardly</hi>: recepissem te, nisi anguste sederem, <hi rend="ital">if I were not in close quarters</hi>, Cic. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anguste putare vitem,</quote> <trans><tr>to prune close</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:16:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 16, 1</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">anguste aliquid deputare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:22:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 22, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quā (re frumentariā) anguste utebatur,</quote> <trans><tr>in small quantity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum navium repperit, ut anguste quindecim milia militum, quingentos equites transportare possent, = vix,</quote> <trans><tr>scarcely fifteen thousand</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 2</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">angustius pabulabantur,</quote> <trans><tr>within narrower range</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliae (arbores) radices angustius diffundunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:37:5" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 37, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quanto sit angustius imperitatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eo anno frumentum propter siccitates angustius provenerat,</quote> <trans><tr>more scantily</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 24</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caesar (nitebatur) ut quam angustissime Pompeium contineret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">furunculus angustissime praecisus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:24:17" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 24, 17</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2588.12" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2588.13" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">within narrow limits</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anguste intraque civiles actiones coërcere rhetoricam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:15:36" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 15, 36</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: haud scio an recte ea virtus frugalitas appellari possit, quod angustius apud Graecos valet, qui frugi homines <foreign lang="greek">xrhsi/mous</foreign> appellant, id est tantum modo utiles, <hi rend="ital">has a narrower meaning</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:8:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 8, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Reliqui habere se videntur angustius, enatant tamen etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>seem to be more hampered</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 31, 87</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2588.14" n="B" level="2"> Esp. of speaking or writing, <hi rend="ital">closely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">briefly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">concisely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without diffuseness</hi>:<cb n="ANHE" />  anguste scribere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:13:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 13, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anguste et exiliter dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:84:289" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 84, 289</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anguste disserere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:41:139" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Part. Or. 41, 139</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">presse et anguste rem definire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:33:117" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 33, 117</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anguste materiem terminare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:4:40" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 4, 40</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pergit idem et urget angustius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:8:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 8, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">concludere brevius angustiusque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 7, 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anhelatio: <entryFree id="n2589" type="main" key="a^nhe_la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănhēlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>anhelo</etym> (post-Aug. for the earlier anhelitus), <sense id="n2589.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a difficulty of breathing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">panting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">puffing.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2589.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">piscium aestivo calore,</quote> <trans><tr>the panting of fish</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 7, 6, § 18</bibl></cit>.—As a disease = <foreign lang="greek">a)=sqma</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">asthma</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 1, 24, § 47</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2589.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">in iis (gemmis) caelestis arcūs anhelatio,</quote> <trans><tr>breathing</tr>, <tr>play of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 6, 23, § 89</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anhelator: <entryFree id="n2590" type="main" key="a^nhe_la_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănhēlātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym> (only postAug.), <sense id="n2590.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who has a difficulty in breathing</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 21, 89, § 156</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:105" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 23, 49, § 105</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anhelitus: <entryFree id="n2591" type="main" key="a^nhe_li^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănhēlĭtus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n2591.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A difficulty of breathing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">panting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">puffing</hi> (class. for the post-Aug. anhelatio): <cit><quote lang="la">ex cursurā anhelitum ducere,</quote> <trans><tr>to pant</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nimiae celeritates gressus cum fiunt, anhelitus moventur,</quote> <trans><tr>quickness of breathing is caused</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:36:131" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 36, 131</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelitum vix sufferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:1:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 1, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelitum recipere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: sublimis anhelitus, <hi rend="ital">deep</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:15:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 15, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">creber,</quote> <trans><tr>quick</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:55" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vastos quatit aeger anhelitus artus,</quote> <trans><tr>painful panting</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:432" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 432</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aridus e lasso veniebat anhelitus ore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:663" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 663</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 54" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 5</bibl>.—As a disease, <hi rend="ital">the asthma</hi> (cf. anhelatio), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 15, 51, § 180</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2591.1" n="II. A." level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">breathing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">breath</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">unguentorum odor, vini anhelitus,</quote> <trans><tr>breath smelling of wine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,019:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Red. in Sen. 7, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">male odorati anhelitus oris,</quote> <trans><tr>bad breath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:521" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 521</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelitum reddere ac per vices recipere,</quote> <trans><tr>to breathe out and in</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:16 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 7, 6, § 16 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2591.2" n="B" level="2"> Metaph., of other things, <hi rend="ital">breath</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exhalation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vapor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">credo etiam anhelitus quosdam fuisse terrarum, quibus inflatae mentes oracula funderent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:50:115" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 50, 115</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">placet Stoicos eos anhelitus terrae, qui frigidi sunt, cum fluere coeperint, ventos esse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 19, 44</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anhelo: <entryFree id="n2592" type="main" key="a^nhe_lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănhēlo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> and <sense id="n2592.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a.</hi> [2. anand halo]. </sense><sense id="n2592.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Verb. neutr.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2592.2" n="A" level="2"> Pr., <hi rend="ital">to move about for breath;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">to draw the breath with great difficulty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to pant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">puff</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gasp</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelat inconstanter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:490" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 490</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum languida anhelant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:864" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 864</bibl></cit>: * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 25</bibl>: anhelans ex imis pulmonibus prae curā spiritus ducebatur, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelans Colla fovet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:837" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 837</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 254 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullus anhelabat sub adunco vomere taurus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:295" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 295</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sudare atque anhelare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:3:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 3, 2</bibl></cit>.— In gen., <hi rend="ital">to breathe</hi> (cf. anhelitus, II.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Apoth. 919</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2592.3" n="B" level="2"> Metaph., of fire: <cit><quote lang="la">fornacibus ignis anhelat,</quote> <trans><tr>roars</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:421" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 421</bibl></cit>.—Of the earth: <cit><quote lang="la">subter anhelat humus,</quote> <trans><tr>heaves</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:1:56" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 1, 56</bibl></cit>.—Of the foaming of the sea, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:9:286" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 9, 286</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of poverty <hi rend="ital">panting</hi> for something: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelans inopia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:9:1:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 9, 1, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2592.4" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Verb. act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to breathe out</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to emit by breathing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">breathe forth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exhale</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nolo verba exiliter exanimata exire, nolo inflata et quasi anhelata gravius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:11:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 11, 38</bibl></cit>: de pectore frigus anhelans Capricornus, vet. poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 44</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelati ignes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:492" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 492</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 12, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">rabiem anhelare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelatis exsurgens ictibus alnus,</quote> <trans><tr>the strokes of the oars made with panting</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:379" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 379</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to pursue</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pant for</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strive after something with eagerness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Catilinam furentem audaciā, scelus anhelantem,</quote> <trans><tr>breathing out wickedness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: anhelans ex imo pectore crudelitatem, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 55</bibl>.!*? Some, as Corssen, Ausspr. II. p. 564, regard the prefix of this word as the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)na/</foreign>; hence, pr. <hi rend="ital">to draw up the breath;</hi> cf. antestor.</sense></entryFree>
anhelus: <entryFree id="n2593" type="main" key="a^nhe_lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănhēlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anhelo</etym>, <sense id="n2593.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">out of breath</hi>, <hi rend="ital">panting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">puffing; attended with short breath</hi> (only in the poets): sic igitur tibi anhela sitis de corpore nostro Abluitur, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:875" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 875</bibl> dub.: <cit><quote lang="la">equi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:250" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 250</bibl></cit>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:418" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 418</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senes,</quote> <trans><tr>who suffer from shortness of breath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:135" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 2, 135</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cursus,</quote> <trans><tr>causing to pant</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:347" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 347</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">febres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:10:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 1, 10, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tussis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:497" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 497</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:680" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 680</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mons,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Rapt. 3, 385</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: nec soli faciles; longique laboris anhelos Avertit patrius genti pavor, <hi rend="ital">panting on account of</hi> <cb n="ANIM" /> <hi rend="ital">the long struggle</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:721" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 15, 721</bibl> (for this <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> v. Roby. II. § 1318).</sense></entryFree>
anhydros: <entryFree id="n2594" type="greek" key="a^nhy_dros1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănhȳdros</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ănȳdr-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/nudros</foreign> (without water), <sense id="n2594.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the narcissus</hi>, as thriving in dry regions, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 55</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2595" type="main" key="A^nhydros2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănhydros</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Ănydr-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2595.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an island in the Ægean Sea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 31, 38, § 137</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aniatrologetus: <entryFree id="n2596" type="greek" key="a^ni^a_tro^lo^ge_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭātrŏlŏgētus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)niatrolo/ghtos</foreign>, <sense id="n2596.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ignorant of medicine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anicianus: <entryFree id="n2597" type="main" key="A^ni^ci^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭcĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n2597.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to Anicius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">named from him</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Anician</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pyra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 15, 16, § 54</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lapicidinae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 2, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:168" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 22, 49, § 168</bibl>: nota, <hi rend="ital">brand of a wine whose age extended back to the consulship of</hi> L. Anicius Gallus (594 A.U.C.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:83:287" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 83, 287</bibl> and 288: <cit><quote lang="la">lectica,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anicilla: <entryFree id="n2598" type="main" key="a^ni^cilla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭcilla</orth> (later <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănŭcella</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n2598.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">doub. dim.</hi> [anicula], <hi rend="ital">a little old woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:45:146" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, 45, 146</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:ad Amic. 1:18" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> ad Amic. 1, 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
anicula: <entryFree id="n2599" type="main" key="a^ni^cu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭcŭla</orth> (sync. <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭcla</orth>, Prud. <foreign lang="greek">p. stef</foreign>. 6, 149), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>anus</etym>, <sense id="n2599.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little old woman</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque illi benivolens extra unam aniculam quisquam aderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 2, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">importunitatem spectate aniculae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec ne aniculae quidem existimant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ista sunt tota commenticia, vix digna lucubratione anicularum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 20</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 77 al" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 77 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
anicularis: <entryFree id="n2600" type="hapax" key="a^ni^cu^la_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭcŭlāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anicula</etym>, <sense id="n2600.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">worthy of an old woman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">after the manner of an old woman</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">verba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:in Psa. 38" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> in Psa. 38</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anidus: <entryFree id="n2601" type="main" key="Anidus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anidus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">mons</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2601.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain in Liguria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:38:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 38, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anien: <entryFree id="n2602" type="main" key="A^ni^e_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭēn</orth>, v. Anio <sense id="n2602.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
anienicola: <entryFree id="n2603" type="main" key="A^ni^e_ni^co^la^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭēnĭcŏlă</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Anio-colo</etym>, <sense id="n2603.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a dweller near the Anio</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">Catilli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:4:225" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 4, 225</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nymphae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:751" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 751</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aniensis: <entryFree id="n2604" type="main" key="A^ni^ensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Anio</etym>, <sense id="n2604.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Anio</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tribus,</quote> <trans><tr>in the Tiburtine region</tr>, <tr>through which the Anio flows</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anienus: <entryFree id="n2605" type="main" key="A^ni^e_nus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭēnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, v. Anio.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2606" type="main" key="A^ni^e_nus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Anio</etym>, <sense id="n2606.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Anio</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fluenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:369" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 369</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:20:8" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 20, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lympha,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:15:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 15, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anigros: <entryFree id="n2607" type="main" key="A^ni_^gro^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănī^grŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/anigros</foreign>, <sense id="n2607.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little river in Elis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rising on Mount Lapithus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Mauropotamo; its waters were muddy and of an unpleasant odor</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:282" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 282</bibl>; cf. Mann. Greece, p. 519.</sense></entryFree>
anilis: <entryFree id="n2608" type="main" key="a^ni_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănīlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anus</etym>, <sense id="n2608.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to an old woman.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2608.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">voltus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:416" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 416</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">passus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:533" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 533</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:1:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 1, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2608.2" n="II" level="1"> Often in a contemptuous sense, <hi rend="ital">like an old woman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">old womanish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anile</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ineptiae paene aniles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:39:93" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 39, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">superstitio imbecilli animi atque anilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:60" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 60</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 28</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 5</bibl>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:6:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 6, 77</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:8:19" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 8, 19</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi> not used.—* <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănīlĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">like an old woman</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:39" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 39</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anilitas: <entryFree id="n2609" type="main" key="a^ni_li^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănīlĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>anilis</etym>, <sense id="n2609.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the old age of a woman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anility</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">cana,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:61:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 61, 158</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 11, 2, 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aniliter: <entryFree id="n2610" type="main" key="a^ni_li^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănīlĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. anilis <sense id="n2610.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
anilitor: <entryFree id="n2611" type="hapax" key="a^ni_li^tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănīlĭtor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>anilis</etym>, <sense id="n2611.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to become an old woman</hi>, App. de Mundo, p. 67, 39 Elm.</sense></entryFree>
anima:
<entryFree id="n2612" type="main" key="a^ni^ma"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭma</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (<sense id="n2612.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> animāï, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 112</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:150" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 150</bibl> et saep.; cf. Neue, Formenl. I. p. 12; Lachm. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 29</bibl>; <case>dat.</case> and <hi rend="ital">abl. plur.</hi> regul. animis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:14:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 14, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> Inst. 6, 20, 19</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 2, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 30</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 33</bibl>; Aug. Civ. Dei, 13, 18; 13, 19; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ver. Relig. 22, 43</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animabus, only in eccl. and later Lat.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:30:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 30, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:77:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Psa. 77, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:11:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 11, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:13:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Heb. 13, 17</bibl> et saep.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 34</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Anim. 33 al.</bibl>; Aug. Civ. Dei, 19, 23; Prud. c. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:531" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> 1, 531</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Rer. Odyss. 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 6, 136 al.</bibl>; Neue, Formenl. I. p. 29) [v. animus], pr. that which blows or breathes; hence, </sense><sense id="n2612.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">air</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a current of air</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a breeze</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wind</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">ne quid animae forte amittat dormiens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:23 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 23 sq.</bibl></cit>: vela ventorum animae immittere, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 234, 9</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 137 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">aurarum leves animae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:236" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 236</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prece quaesit Ventorum pavidus paces animasque secundas,</quote> <trans><tr>he anxiously implores a lull in the winds and a favoring breeze</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1229" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 1229</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impellunt animae lintea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 12, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ne dubites quin haec animaï turbida sit vis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:693" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 693</bibl></cit>: Quantum ignes animaeque<pb n="121" /> <cb n="ANIM" />  valent (of the wind in the workshop of Vulcan), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:403" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 403</bibl>.—Also of a flame of fire (blowing like the air): noctilucam tollo, ad focum fero, inflo; anima reviviscit, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 234, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2612.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2612.3" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">the air</hi>, as an element, like fire, water, and earth (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): aqua, terra, anima et sol, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:4:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 4, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui quattuor ex rebus posse omnia rentur, Ex igni, terrā atque animā, procrescere et imbri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:715" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 715</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut, quem ad modum ignis animae, sic anima aquae, quodque anima aquae, id aqua terrae proportione redderet. Earum quattuor rerum etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tim. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utrum (animus) sit ignis, an anima, an sanguis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 39, 124</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si anima est (animus), fortasse dissipabitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:1:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 1, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 25, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si deus aut anima aut ignis est, idem est animus hominis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 26, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus ex inflammatā animā constat, ut potissimum videri video Panaetio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 18, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Semina terrarumque animaeque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 32</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2612.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The air inhaled and exhaled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">breath</hi> (concr.); while spiritus denotes orig. breathing (abstr.; very freq. in prose and poetry); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:54:136" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 54, 136</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">excipiat animam eam, quae ducta sit spiritu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 5, 2, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animam compressi, aurem admovi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 6, 28</bibl></cit> Ruhnk.: <cit><quote lang="la">animam recipe,</quote> <trans><tr>take breath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 3, 2, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum spiritus ejus (sc. Demosthenis) esset angustior, tantum continendā animā in dicendo est assecutus, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:61:261" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 61, 261</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne circuitus ipse verborum sit longior quam vires atque anima patiatur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 49, 191</bibl></cit>; 3, 46, 181; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:54:136" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 54, 136</bibl>: fetida anima nasum oppugnat, Titin. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 233, 5</bibl> (Com. Rel. p. 136 Rib.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0013,001:ib. 9" default="NO"><author>Caecil.</author> ib. 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui non modo animum integrum, sed ne animam quidem puram conservare potuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 58</bibl></cit>: animas et olentia Medi Ora fovent illo, <hi rend="ital">with this the Medes correct their breath</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 134</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">respiramen iterque Eripiunt animae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 143</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:425" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 1, 425</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animae gravitas,</quote> <trans><tr>bad smell of the breath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 9, 35, § 91</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 11, 37, 72, § 188</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:132 al" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 25, 64, § 132 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">artavit clusitque animam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:370" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 4, 370</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes illorum abominatio animae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 11, 20</bibl></cit>.—Of breath exhaled: <cit><quote lang="la">inspirant graves animas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:498" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 498</bibl></cit>.— Of the air breathed into a musical instrument, <hi rend="ital">a breath of air</hi>, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 233</bibl>. 13.—Since air is a necessary condition of life, </sense><sense id="n2612.5" n="C. 1." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The vital principle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the breath of life</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus est, quo sapimus, anima, quā vivimus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 426, 27</bibl></cit> (hence anima denotes <hi rend="ital">the animal principle of life</hi>, in distinction from animus, the spiritual, reasoning, willing principle; very freq. in Lucr. and class.): Mater est terra, ea parit corpus, animam aether adjugat, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 75, 11</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 88 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">tunc cum primis ratione sagaci, Unde anima atque animi constet natura, videndum,</quote> <trans><tr>whence spring life and the nature of the mind</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 131</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:158" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 158</bibl> sq.; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:417 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 417 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:565" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 565</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:705" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 705</bibl>; 2, 950; 4, 922; 4, 944; 4, 959; 6, 798; 6, 1223; <cit><quote lang="la">6, 1233 et saep.: deus totus est sensuus, totus visuus, totus audituus, totus animae, totus animi, totus sui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 7, 5, § 14</bibl></cit> Jan: <cit><quote lang="la">quaedam (animantia) animum habent, quaedam tantum animam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 58" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anima omnis carnis in sanguine est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:17:14 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 17, 14 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2612.6" n="2" level="3"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">life</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum anima corpus liquerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag. Rel. p. 214" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 214</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">Animae pauxillulum in me habet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0112,001:Com. Rel. p. 14" default="NO"><author>Naev.</author> Com. Rel. p. 14</bibl></cit> Rib.: Date ferrum, quī me animā privem, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 474, 31</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 37 Rib.): me dicabo atque animam devōvo (i. e. devovero) hostibus, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 98, 12</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 283 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">conficit animam vis volneris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag. Rel. p. 209" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 209</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">adimere animam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 137</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 5, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">exstinguere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">relinquere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 4, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">edere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de vestrā vitā, de conjugum vestrarum ac liberorum animā judicandum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 9, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si tibi omnia sua praeter animam tradidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">libertas et anima nostra in dubio est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pauci, quibus relicta est anima, clausi in tenebris, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 14, 15</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">retinere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 31:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 31, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de manu viri et fratris ejus requiram animam hominis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 9, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 2, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:14:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Cor. 14, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animam agere,</quote> <trans><tr>to give up the ghost</tr>, <tr>to die</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:9:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 9, 19</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so also efflare,</quote> <trans><tr>to expire</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:99" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 99</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">exhalare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:528" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 528</bibl></cit>; <cb n="ANIM" /> and, exspirare, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:106" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 106</bibl> (cf. in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">qumo
 a)popne/ein, yuxh
 e)kpne/ein, bi/on a)poyu/xein</foreign>, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">deponere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ponere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:10:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 10, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">13, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amittere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1233" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1233</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">emittere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 9, 3</bibl></cit> Br. (so in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)fie/nai th
 yuxh/n</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">proicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:436" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 436</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">purpuream vomit ille animam, said of a wounded man,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 349</bibl></cit>.—In <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:16:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 16, 25</bibl> and 26, anima in v. 25 seems to pass to the higher meaning, <hi rend="ital">soul</hi>, (cf. infra, II. D.) in v. 26, as <foreign lang="greek">h( yuxh/</foreign> in the original also can do.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">anima amphorae,</quote> <trans><tr>the fumes of wine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 3, 1</bibl></cit>: Ni ego illi puteo, si occepso, animam omnem intertraxero, <hi rend="ital">draw up all the life of that well</hi>, i. e. draw it dry, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 41</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpus imperii unius praesidis nutu, quasi animā et mente, regeretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:3" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accentus quasi anima vocis est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1321,001:page=67" default="NO"><author>Pompon.</author> p. 67</bibl></cit> Lind.—Prov.: animam debere, <hi rend="ital">to owe life itself</hi>, of one deeply in debt: <cit><quote lang="la">quid si animam debet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 4, 3, 56</bibl></cit> (Graecum proverbium: <foreign lang="greek">kai\ au)th
 th
 yuxh
 o)fei/lei</foreign>, Don.).—Metaph., applied to plants and other things possessing organic life, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 58" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 58</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 21, 35, § 152</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:3" default="NO" valid="yes">31, 1, 1, § 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:16 al" default="NO" valid="yes">14, 1, 3, § 16 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2612.7" n="3" level="3"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a creature endowed with</hi> anima, <hi rend="ital">a living being</hi>: ova parere solet genu' pennis condecoratum, non animam, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:10:18" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, 10, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hi (deos) fibris animāque litant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:246" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 246</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Josh. 11, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:9:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 9, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 2, 43</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">animae rationis expertes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 3, 8</bibl></cit>.—So esp. of men (as we also say <hi rend="ital">souls</hi> for <hi rend="ital">persons;</hi> <usg type="style">poet.</usg> or in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">egregias animas, quae sanguine nobis Hanc patriam peperere suo, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animae quales nec candidiores, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 41</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:322" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 322</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vos Treveri et ceterae servientium animae,</quote> <trans><tr>ministering spirits</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 32</bibl></cit>.—So in enumerations in eccl. Lat.: <cit><quote lang="la">hos genuit Jacob sedecim animas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:46:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 46, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">46, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 2, 41</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 14</bibl>.—Of slaves (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">merces animarum hominum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:18:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Apoc. 18, 13</bibl></cit> (after the use of <foreign lang="greek">h( yuxh/</foreign> and <foreign />). —Hence, also, <hi rend="ital">souls separated from the body</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the shades of the Lower World</hi>, <hi rend="ital">manes</hi>: Unde (ex Averno) animae excitantur, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:16:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 16, 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu pias laetis animas reponis Sedibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:10:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 10, 17</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:8:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 8, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animamque sepulcro Condimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 67</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:612" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 612</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:8:488" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 488</bibl>; 10, 41; 14, 411; 15, 158; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:88" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 88</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">vita: tenuīs sine corpore vitas volitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:292" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 292</bibl></cit>.—So in eccl. Lat. of <hi rend="ital">departed spirits</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">timete eum, qui potest animam et corpus perdere in Gehennam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 10, 28</bibl></cit> bis: <cit><quote lang="la">non derelinques animam meam in Inferno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 2, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">20, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2612.8" n="4" level="3"> As expressive of love: <cit><quote lang="la">vos, meae carissimae animae,</quote> <trans><tr>my dearest souls</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:14:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 14, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">14, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pro quā non metuam mori, Si parcent animae fata superstiti,</quote> <trans><tr>the dear surviving life</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:9:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 9, 12</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">animae dimidium meae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meae pars animae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 17, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2612.9" n="D" level="2"> Sometimes for animus, as <hi rend="ital">the rational soul of man.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2612.10" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The mind as the seat of thought</hi> (cf. animus, II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">anima rationis consiliique particeps,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N.D.1, 31, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causa in animā sensuque meo penitus affixa atque insita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingenii facinora, sicut anima, immortalia sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 2, 2</bibl></cit>.—So often in eccl. Lat.: <cit><quote lang="la">ad te Domine, levavi animam meam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:24:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 24, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">102, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">118, 129</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnificat anima mea Dominum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 1, 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:15:24 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 15, 24 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2612.11" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">As the seat of feeling</hi> (cf. animus, II. B.): sapimus animo, fruimur animā: sine animo anima est debilis, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 426, 29</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 175 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">desiderat anima mea ad te, Deus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:41:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 41, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tristis est anima mea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:26:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 26, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:10:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 10, 27</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n2612.12" n="E" level="2"> For <hi rend="ital">consciousness</hi> (cf. animus, II. A. 3. and conscientia, II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum perhibetur animam liquisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:598" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 598</bibl></cit>; in this phrase animus is more common.</sense></entryFree>
animabilis: <entryFree id="n2613" type="main" key="a^ni^ma_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, Cic.N.D. 2, 36, 91; where others, as B. and K., read animalis, q. v.</entryFree>
animadversio: <entryFree id="n2614" type="main" key="a^ni^madversi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmadversĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>animadverto</etym>, <sense id="n2614.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the perception</hi> or <hi rend="ital">observation</hi> of an object; <hi rend="ital">consideration</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attention</hi> (in good prose, most freq. in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n2614.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">notatio naturae et animadversio peperit artem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:55:183" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 55, 183</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc totum est sive artis sive animadversionis sive consuetudinis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:34:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 34, 147</bibl></cit>;
