so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:9:30 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 9, 30 al.</bibl>—Hence, in reference to one's self, <hi rend="ital">self-inspection</hi>, <cb n="ANIM" /> <hi rend="ital">watchfulness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">excitanda animadversio et diligentia, ut ne quid temere agamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:29:103" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 29, 103</bibl></cit>; and in gen. <hi rend="ital">inquiry</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaestio atque animadversio in aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 18</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2614.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n2614.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Reproach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">censure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec effugere possemus animadversionem, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:57:195" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 57, 195</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2614.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Chastisement</hi>, <hi rend="ital">punishment</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animadversio Dollabellae in audaces servos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paterna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis autem animadversio et castigatio contumeliā vacare debet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:25:88" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 25, 88</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:10:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 10, 35</bibl>: in proelium exarsere, ni valens animadversione paucorum oblitos jam Batavos imperii admonuisset, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:24" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:11 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 11 al.</bibl>—So of the punishment decreed by the censors for crime committed (usu. called nota censoria): <cit><quote lang="la">notiones animadversionesque censorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:31:111" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 31, 111</bibl></cit> B. and K.: <cit><quote lang="la">censoriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:42:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 42, 119</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 42, 117</bibl>.—And by the dictator: <cit><quote lang="la">dictatoria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:68:5" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 68, 5</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:19" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 19</bibl> Bremi.</sense></entryFree>
animadversor: <entryFree id="n2615" type="hapax" key="a^ni^madversor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmadversor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2615.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an observer</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acres ac diligentes animadversores vitiorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:41:146" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 41, 146</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
animadverto: <entryFree id="n2616" type="main" key="a^ni^madverto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmadverto</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">-vorto</orth>), <itype>ti, sum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>contr. from animum adverto, which orthography is very freq. in the anteclass. period; cf. adverto, II. B.</etym> (scarcely found in any poet beside Ter. and Verg.), <sense id="n2616.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to direct the mind</hi> or <hi rend="ital">attention</hi> to a thing, <hi rend="ital">to attend to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">give heed to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to take heed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consider</hi>, <hi rend="ital">regard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">observe.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2616.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2616.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">alios tuam rem credidisti magis quam tete animum advorsuros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">atque haec in bello plura et majora videntur timentibus, eadem non tam animadvertuntur in pace,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed animadvertendum est diligenter, quae natura rerum sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:20:69" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 20, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dignitas tua facit, ut animadvertatur quicquid facias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:27:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 11, 27, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 6, 2</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to think of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud me non animadvertisse moleste ferrem, ut ascriberem, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:20:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 20, 5</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">animos advertere, ne,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 45</bibl></cit>).—</sense><sense id="n2616.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., as t. t. </sense><sense id="n2616.4" n="1" level="3"> Of the lictor, whose duty it was <hi rend="ital">to give attention</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to see</hi>, that the consul, when he appeared, should receive due homage (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 64" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 64</bibl>; Schwarz ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:23" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 23</bibl>, and Smith, Dict. Antiq., s. v. lictor): <cit><quote lang="la">consul animadvertere proximum lictorem jussit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 44 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2616.5" n="2" level="3"> Of the people, to whom the lictor gave orders <hi rend="ital">to pay attention</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to pay regard to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">consule theatrum introeunte, cum lictor animadverti ex more jussisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:80" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 80</bibl></cit> Ruhnk.—</sense><sense id="n2616.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, as a consequence of attention. </sense><sense id="n2616.7" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To remark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">notice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">observe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perceive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">see</hi> (in a more general sense than above; the most usu. signif. of this word). </sense><sense id="n2616.8" n="a" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ecquid attendis? ecquid animadvertis horum silentium?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 8, 20</bibl></cit>: utcumque animadversa aut existimata erunt, Liv. praef. <hi rend="ital">med.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">his animadversis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:259" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 259</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 123</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">Equidem etiam illud animadverto, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:12:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 12, 37</bibl></cit> Beier.: <cit><quote lang="la">nutrix animadvertit puerum dormientem circumplicatum serpentis amplexu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:36:79" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 36, 79</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2616.9" n="b" level="4"> With <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">postquam id vos velle animum advorteram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:8:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 8, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui non animadverterit innocentes illos natos, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 6, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">turrim conlucere animadvertit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2616.10" n="c" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">ind. quest.</hi>: quod quale sit, etiam in bestiis quibusdam animadverti potest, Cic.Am. 8, 27.—</sense><sense id="n2616.11" n="B" level="2"> In a pregn. sense, <hi rend="ital">to discern</hi> something, or, in gen., <hi rend="ital">to apprehend</hi>, <hi rend="ital">understand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">comprehend</hi>, <hi rend="ital">know</hi> (less freq. than the synn. cognoscere, intellegere, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">boni seminis sues animadvertuntur a facie et progenie,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:4:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nonne animadvertis, quam multi effugerint?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:37:89" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 37, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut adsint, cognoscant, animadvertant, quid de religione ... existimandum sit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 6, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animadverti enim et didici ex tuis litteris te, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2616.12" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To notice a wrong</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to censure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">blame</hi>, <hi rend="ital">chastise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">punish</hi> (cf. the Engl. phrase <hi rend="ital">to attend to one</hi>, for <hi rend="ital">to punish</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">Ea primum ab illo animadvortenda injuriast,</quote> <trans><tr>deserves to be punished</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 129</bibl></cit> (animadvortenda = castiganda, vindicanda, Don.): <cit><quote lang="la">O facinus animadvortendum,</quote> <trans><tr>O crime worthy of punishment</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 4, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animadvertenda peccata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res a magistratibus animadvertenda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque animadvertere neque vincire nisi sacerdotibus permissum = morte multare,</quote> <trans><tr>to punish with death</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 7</bibl></cit>.—Esp. freq. in judicial proceedings as t. t., constr. with <hi rend="ital">in aliquem</hi>: qui institueras<pb n="122" /> <cb n="ANIM" />  animadvertere in eos, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">imperiti, si in hunc animadvertissem, crudeliter et regie factum esse dicerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:12:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 12, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui in alios animadvertisset indictā causā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 51:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 51, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Marcianum Icelum, ut in libertum, palam animadversum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 68</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 85</bibl>; 4, 49; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:15" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:19:8 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 19, 8 al.</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, effect for cause, animadverti,</quote> <trans><tr>to offend</tr>, <tr>be censurable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:3:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 3, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
animaequus: <entryFree id="n2617" type="main" key="a^ni^maequus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭm-aequus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>animus</etym>, <sense id="n2617.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">not easily moved;</hi> also <hi rend="ital">of good courage</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">animaequior esto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,050:4:5:21:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Bar. 4, 5, 21, 30</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:10:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 10, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animaequiores estote filii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,050:4:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Bar. 4, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,033:18:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Sap. 18, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:27:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 27, 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
animal: <entryFree id="n2618" type="main" key="a^ni^ma^l"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmăl</orth>, <itype>ālis</itype> (<case>abl.</case> animali; but Rhem. Palaem. p. 1372 P. gives animale), <gen>n.</gen> <etym>as if for animale, which is found in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:10:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 10, 31</bibl> MS.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:635" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 635</bibl>; cf. animalis</etym>, <sense id="n2618.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a living being</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an animal.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2618.1" n="I" level="1"> In the widest sense, <foreign lang="greek">zw=on</foreign> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">zwo/s</foreign> = living): <cit><quote lang="la">inanimum est omne, quod pulsu agitatur externo, quod autem est animal, id motu cietur interiore et suo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:23:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 23, 54</bibl></cit>, where it is opp. to the <pos>adj.</pos> inanimum, and therefore is equivalent to <hi rend="ital">animale;</hi> cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">uti possint sentire animalia quaeque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:973" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 973</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum omne animal patibilem naturam habeat, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:12:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 12, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 47, 122</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">formicae, animal minumum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 15, 13, § 65</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:33" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 4, 6, § 33</bibl> et saep.—Of men: <cit><quote lang="la">animal providum et sagax homo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:7:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 7, 22</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sanctius his animal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bicipites hominum aliorumve animalium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Vitellius) umbraculis hortorum abditus, ut ignava animalia, quibus cibum suggeras, jacent torpentque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam fera animalia, si clausa teneas, virtutis obliviscuntur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 64</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animalia maris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 15, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 63, 83, § 171</bibl>.—Also of the universe, considered as an animated existence: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc mundum animal esse, idque intellegens et divinā providentiā constitutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tim. 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2618.2" n="II" level="1"> Sometimes in a more restricted sense, as antith. to man, <hi rend="ital">a beast</hi> (as in Heb. <foreign />, animal, from <foreign />, to live): <cit><quote lang="la">multa ab animalium vocibus tralata in homines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:5:100" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, 5, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alia animalia gradiendo, alia serpendo, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:47:122" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 47, 122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animalia inusitata ceteris gentibus, nisi invecta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:9:16" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 9, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep 76:6" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep 76, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quod animal in mustum inciderit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:31" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quod animal aurem intraverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 4, 7, § 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">similitudo non ab hominibus modo petitur, verum etiam ab animalibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:57" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 57</bibl></cit>.—Hence, with contempt, of a man: <cit><quote lang="la">funestum illud animal, ex nefariis stupris concretum,</quote> <trans><tr>that pernicious brute</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
animalis: <entryFree id="n2619" type="main" key="a^ni^ma_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anima</etym>. <sense id="n2619.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Consisting of air</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aërial</hi> (cf. anima, I. and II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">simplex est natura animantis, ut vel terrena vel ignea vel animalis vel umida,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:14:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 14, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturam esse quattuor omnia gignentium corporum ... terrena et humida ... reliquae duae partes, una ignea, altera animalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:17:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 17, 40</bibl></cit>: animalis spirabilisque natura, cui nomen est aër (B. and K.; <cit><quote lang="la">others read animabilis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:36:91" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 36, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spirabilis, id est animalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:18:42" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 18, 42</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2619.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Animate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">living</hi> (cf. anima, II. C.). </sense><sense id="n2619.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">corpora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:727" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 727</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pulli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:927" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 927</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">colligata corpora vinculis animalibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tim. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intellegentia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut mutum in simulacrum ex animali exemplo veritas transferatur,</quote> <trans><tr>from the living original</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2619.3" n="B" level="2"> In the lang. of sacrifice: <cit><quote lang="la">hostia animalis,</quote> <trans><tr>an offering of which only the life is consecrated to the gods</tr>, <tr>but the flesh is destined for the priests and others</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 3, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 3, 231</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 56</bibl>.—Dii animales, <hi rend="ital">gods who were formerly men</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 3, 168</bibl>.—* <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmālĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">like an animal</hi> (opp. spiritualiter): <cit><quote lang="la">animaliter vivere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Retr. 1:26:67" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Retr. 1, 26, 67</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
animans: <entryFree id="n2620" type="main" key="a^ni^mans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmans</orth>, v. <itype>animo</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
animatio: <entryFree id="n2621" type="main" key="a^ni^ma_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>animo</etym>, <sense id="n2621.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a quickening</hi>, <hi rend="ital">animating</hi> (extremely rare). </sense><sense id="n2621.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">arboris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2621.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, concr., <hi rend="ital">a living being</hi>: divinae animationis species, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:10:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tim. 10, 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
animator: <entryFree id="n2622" type="main" key="a^ni^ma_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2622.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">he that quickens</hi><cb n="ANIM" />  or <hi rend="ital">animates</hi> (post-class., oftenest in the Church fathers): <cit><quote lang="la">animarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 48</bibl></cit>; so Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>. 10, 788.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">marmoris signifex animator,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> 1, p. 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
animatrix: <entryFree id="n2623" type="hapax" key="a^ni^ma_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmātrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>animator</etym>, <sense id="n2623.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">she that quickens</hi> or <hi rend="ital">animates</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">confessionis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Gnost. 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
animatus: <entryFree id="n2624" type="main" key="a^ni^ma_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. <itype>animo</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2625" type="hapax" key="a^ni^ma_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>animo</etym>, <sense id="n2625.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a breathing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animatu carere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 3, 2, § 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
animicida: <entryFree id="n2626" type="hapax" key="a^ni^mi^ci_da"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmĭcīda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>anima - caedo</etym>, <sense id="n2626.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">soul-destroyer</hi>, as transl. of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">yuxofqo/ros</foreign>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 1, 1, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
animitus: <entryFree id="n2627" type="gloss" key="a^ni^mi^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmĭtus</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>animus</etym>, <sense id="n2627.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">heartily</hi>, like oculitus, medullitus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 147, 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
animo: <entryFree id="n2628" type="main" key="a^ni^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>anima and animus</etym>. <sense id="n2628.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2628.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To fill with breath</hi> or <hi rend="ital">air</hi> (cf. anima, I. and II.): <cit><quote lang="la">duas tibias uno spiritu,</quote> <trans><tr>to blow upon</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. 3, p. 341, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bucinas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 6, p. 196</bibl></cit>.—More freq., </sense><sense id="n2628.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To quicken</hi>, <hi rend="ital">animate</hi> (cf. anima, II. C.): quicquid est hoc, omnia animat, format, alit, auget, creat, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:717" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 717</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitaliter esse animata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 145</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">formare, figurare, colorare, animare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:39:110" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 39, 110</bibl></cit>. stellae divinis animatae mentibus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 15, 13, § 66</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n2628.3" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To endow with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to give</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a particular temperament</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disposition of mind</hi> (cf. animus, II. B. 1. b.): <cit><quote lang="la">utcumque temperatus sit aër, ita pueros orientes animari atque formari, ex eoque ingenia, mores, animum fingi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:42:89" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 42, 89</bibl></cit>: Mattiaci ipso terrae suae solo ac caelo acrius animantur, i. e. ferociores redduntur, <hi rend="ital">are rendered more spirited</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 29</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2628.4" n="D" level="2"> In Ovid in a pregnant signif.: aliquid in aliquid animare, <hi rend="ital">to transform a lifeless object to a living being</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to change into by giving life</hi> (cf. anima, II. C. 3.): <cit><quote lang="la">guttas animavit in angues,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:619" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 619</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Nymphas animatā classe marinas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:566" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 566</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2628.5" n="E" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of colors, <hi rend="ital">to enliven</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid Apellei gaudent animāsse colores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:2:64" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 2, 64</bibl></cit>.—Of torches, <hi rend="ital">to light</hi> or <hi rend="ital">kindle</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animare ad crimina taxos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Rapt. 3, 386</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes = recreare, <hi rend="ital">to refresh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">revive</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cibo potuque animavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 126" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 126</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">florem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 23, 27, § 77</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 4, 10</bibl>; or in gen., <hi rend="ital">to encourage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">help</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ope animari, Cod. Th. 6, 4, 21, § 3: copiis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 14, 4, 10, § 5</bibl></cit>.—And with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> = incitare, <hi rend="ital">to move</hi>, <hi rend="ital">incite to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ut hortatu vestro Eustathius, quae de scommate paulo ante dixerit, animetur aperire,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 7, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n2628.6" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Animated</hi> (cf. anima, II. C.): virum virtute verā vivere animatum addecet, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:17" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2628.7" n="b" level="4"> (Acc. to C.) <hi rend="ital">Brought</hi> or <hi rend="ital">put into a particular frame of mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disposed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inclined</hi>, <hi rend="ital">minded</hi>, in some way (freq. and class.): <cit><quote lang="la">hoc animo decet animatos esse amatores probos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 3, 20</bibl></cit>: avi et atavi nostri, quom allium ac caepe eorum verba olerent, tamen optime animati erant, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 201, 7</bibl> (where the play upon olere and animati is to be noticed): <cit><quote lang="la">animatus melius quam paratus,</quote> <trans><tr>better disposed than prepared</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">socii infirme animati,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sic animati esse debetis, ut si ille adesset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 9, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut quem ad modum in se quisque, sic in amicum sit animatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:16:57" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Am. 16, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insulas non nullas bene animatas confirmavit,</quote> <trans><tr>well affected</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,005:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Cim. 2, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">male animatus erga principem exercitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">circa aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:14:1" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 14, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hostili animo adversus rem publicam animatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:4:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: animatus in necem alicujus, Macr S. 1, 11.—In Plaut. with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: si quid animatus es facere, Truc. 5, 74.—</sense><sense id="n2628.8" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Endowed with courage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">courageous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stouthearted</hi> (cf. animus, II. 2. a. and animosus; <cit><quote lang="la">only in ante-class. poetry): milites armati atque animati probe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 9, 18</bibl></cit>: cum animatus iero, satis armatus sum, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 233, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hostis animatus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> p. 233, 18.—* <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> Auct. Itin. Alex. 13.— <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi> not used.—</sense><sense id="n2628.9" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be animate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">living</hi> (cf. anima, II. C.); so only <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭ-mans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype> (<case>abl.</case> com. animante, but animanti in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=6" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tim. 6</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> animantium in Cic., animantum in Lucr., <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 4, 374</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. 64, p. 536</bibl>), </sense><sense id="n2628.10" n="a" level="4"> <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">animate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">living</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos (deos) Vitellius ne animantes quidem esse concedat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:4:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundum ipsum animantem sapientemque esse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 10, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animans composque rationis mundus est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 8, 22</bibl></cit>. —Hence, </sense><sense id="n2628.11" n="b" level="4"> <pos>Subst.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">any living</hi>, <hi rend="ital">animate being;<cb n="ANIM" />  an animal</hi> (orig. in a wider sense than <hi rend="ital">animal</hi>, since it included men, animals, and plants; but usu., like that word, for animals in opp. to men. The gender varies in the best class. writers between <hi rend="ital">masc.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi> When it designates man, it is <hi rend="ital">masc.;</hi> brutes, com. <hi rend="ital">fem.;</hi> in its widest sense, it is <hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">sunt quaedam, quae animam habent, nec sunt animalia, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 58:10 sq" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 58, 10 sq.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:669" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 669</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:943" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 943</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus omne animantum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:194" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 194</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:350" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 350</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:1033" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 1033</bibl>; 1, 1038; 2, 78; 2, 880; 2, 921; 2, 943; 2, 1063; 2, 1071; 3, 266; 3, 417; 3, 720; 5, 431; 5, 855; <cit><quote lang="la">5, 917: animantium genera quattuor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tim. 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">11</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animantium aliae coriis tectae sunt, aliae villis vestitae, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:47:121" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 47, 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ceteras animantes abjecisset ad pastum, solum hominem erexit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:9:26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 9, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animantia, quae sunt nobis nota,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tim. 4</bibl></cit>.—Of animals, <hi rend="ital">living beings</hi>, as opp. to plants: <cit><quote lang="la">Jam vero vites sic claviculis adminicula tamquam manibus adprehendunt atque ita se erigunt, ut animantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:47:120" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 47, 120</bibl></cit>.— Of man: hic stilus haud petet ultro Quemquam animantem, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:1:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 1, 40</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.</sense></entryFree>
animose: <entryFree id="n2629" type="main" key="a^ni^mo_se_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmōsē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. 2. animosus <sense id="n2629.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
animositas: <entryFree id="n2630" type="main" key="a^ni^mo_si^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmōsĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>animosus</etym> (only post-class.). <sense id="n2630.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Boldness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">courage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spirit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">resistendi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 16, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 4, 3</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2630.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Vehemence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impetuosity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ardor</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Somn. Scip. 1, 6</bibl>; in <number>plur.</number>, * <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 162" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 162</bibl>, and Civ. Dei, 14, 2 al.—</sense><sense id="n2630.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Wrath</hi>, <hi rend="ital">enmity</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">iracundia animositatis illius (Dei) subversio illius est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:1:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 1, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:12:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Cor. 12, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:11:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Heb. 11, 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
animosus: <entryFree id="n2631" type="main" key="a^ni^mo_sus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anima</etym>. <sense id="n2631.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Full of air</hi>, <hi rend="ital">airy</hi> (cf. anima, I. and II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">guttura,</quote> <trans><tr>through which the breath passes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 134</bibl></cit>.—Of the wind. <hi rend="ital">blowing violently</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Eurus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:441" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 441</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ventus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:6:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 6, 51</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2631.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Full of life</hi>, <hi rend="ital">living</hi>, <hi rend="ital">animate</hi>, of pictures, etc. (cf. anima, II. C.): <cit><quote lang="la">Gloria Lysippost animosa effingere signa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:8:9" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 8, 9</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> of 1. animosus not used.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2632" type="main" key="a^ni^mo_sus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>animus</etym>. <sense id="n2632.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Full of courage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spirited</hi>, <hi rend="ital">undaunted</hi> (cf. animus, II. B. 2. a.): <cit><quote lang="la">mancipia neque formidolosa neque animosa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:17:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 17, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in gladiatoriis pugnis timidos odisse solemus, fortes et animosos servari cupimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex quo fit, ut animosior etiam senectus sit quam adulescentia et fortior,</quote> <trans><tr>shows more courage and valor</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 20</bibl></cit> equus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 84</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:6:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 4, 6, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animosum (equorum) pectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bella,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:59" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Parthus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:19:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 19, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hector,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:7:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 7, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rebus angustis animosus atque Fortis appare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:10:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 2, 10, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frigus animosum,</quote> <trans><tr>fear coupled with courage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:6:395" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 6, 395</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2632.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Proud</hi> on account of something: <cit><quote lang="la">En ego (Latona) vestra parens, vobis animosa creatis,</quote> <trans><tr>proud to have borne you</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:206" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 206</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spoliis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:11:552" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 552</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2632.2" n="III" level="1"> Adeo animosus corruptor, <hi rend="ital">that fears</hi> or <hi rend="ital">avoids no expense</hi> or <hi rend="ital">danger in bribery</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 24</bibl>.—So, also, emptor animosus, <hi rend="ital">sparing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fearing no expense</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:17:1:36" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 17, 1, 36</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:47" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 47</bibl>: gemmas semper animosissime comparāsse prodiderunt).—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmōsē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">in a spirited manner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">courageously</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eagerly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animose et fortiter aliquid facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnifice, graviter animoseque vivere,</quote> <trans><tr>independently</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:26:92" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 26, 92</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:23:51" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 4, 23, 51</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animose liceri,</quote> <trans><tr>to bid eagerly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:2:29" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 10, 2, 29</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animosius dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 6:37" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 6, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animosius se gerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:8:2" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 8, 2</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.—Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gemmas animosissime comparare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:47" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 47</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
animula: <entryFree id="n2633" type="main" key="a^ni^mu^la1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>anima</etym>, <sense id="n2633.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little soul</hi>, <hi rend="ital">life</hi>: aegra et saucia, Auct. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:11:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 11, 4</bibl> (Hertz, anima): mulierculae, Sulp. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 5, 11</bibl>: vagula, blandula, etc., Hadr. Imp. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Hadr. 25</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2579</bibl> and 4761; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2634" type="gloss" key="A^ni^mu^la2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭmŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>: urbs parvarum opum in Apuliā, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 25</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 53</bibl>; cf. Philarg. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 134</bibl>.</entryFree>
animulus: <entryFree id="n2635" type="main" key="a^ni^mu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>animus</etym>, only in the voc. as term of endearment (cf. animus, II. B. 2. f.): <sense id="n2635.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">Mi animule,</quote> <trans><tr>my heart</tr>, <tr>my darling</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Animule mi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 2, 3, 11</bibl></cit>. <pb n="123" /> <cb n="ANIM" /></sense></entryFree>
animus: <entryFree id="n2636" type="main" key="a^ni^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănĭmus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>a Graeco-Italic form of <foreign lang="greek">a)/nemos</foreign> = wind (as ego, lego, of <foreign lang="greek">e)gw/, le/gw</foreign>); cf. Sanscr. an = to breathe, anas = breath, anilas = wind; Goth. uz-ana = exspiro; Erse, anal = breath; Germ. Unst = a storm (so, <foreign /> sometimes); but Curt. does not extend the connection to <foreign lang="greek">*a*w, a)/hmi</foreign> = to blow; a modification of animus—by making which the Romans took a step in advance of the Greeks, who used <foreign lang="greek">h( yuxh/</foreign> for both these ideas—is anima, which has the physical meaning of <foreign lang="greek">a)/nemos</foreign>, so that Cic. was theoretically right, but historically wrong, when he said, ipse animus ab animā dictus est, Tusc. 1, 9, 19; after the same analogy we have from <foreign lang="greek">yu/xw</foreign> = to breathe, blow, <foreign lang="greek">yuxh/</foreign> = breath, life, soul; from <foreign lang="greek">pne/w</foreign> = to breathe, <foreign lang="greek">pneu=ma</foreign> = air, breath, life, in class. Greek, and = spirit, a spiritual being, in Hellenistic Greek; from spiro = to breathe, blow, spiritus = breath, breeze, energy, high spirit, and <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and post-Aug. = soul, mind; the Engl. ghost = Germ. Geist may be comp. with Germ. giessen and <foreign lang="greek">xe/w</foreign>, to pour, and for this interchange of the ideas of gases and liquids, cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 22</bibl>: insula adspiratur freto Gallico, <hi rend="ital">is flowed upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">washed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by the Gallic Strait;</hi> the Sanscr. ātman = breath, soul, with which comp. <foreign lang="greek">a)u+tmh/</foreign> = breath; Germ. Odem = breath, and Athem = breath, soul, with which group Curt. connects <foreign lang="greek">au)/w, a)/hmi</foreign>; the Heb. <foreign /> = breath, life, soul; and <foreign /> = breath, wind, life, spirit, soul or mind</etym>. <sense id="n2636.0" n="I" level="1"> In a general sense, <hi rend="ital">the rational soul in man</hi> (in opp. to the body, <hi rend="ital">corpus</hi>, and to the physical life, <hi rend="ital">anima</hi>), <foreign lang="greek">h( yuxh/</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">humanus animus decerptus ex mente divinā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:13:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 13, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Corpus animum praegravat, Atque affixit humo divinae particulam aurae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">credo deos immortales sparsisse animos in corpora humana, ut essent qui terras tuerentur etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:21:77" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 21, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eas res tueor animi non corporis viribus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 38</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:23:79" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 23, 79</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (res) vel infirmis corporibus animo tamen administratur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:6:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 6, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:29:102" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 29, 102</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes animi cruciatus et corporis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">levantes Corpus et animum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 141</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">formam et figuram animi magis quam corporis complecti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animi validus et corpore ingens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 15, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aristides primus animum pinxit et sensus hominis expressit, quae vocantur Graece ethe, item perturbationes,</quote> <trans><tr>first painted the soul</tr>, <tr>put a soul into his figures</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 98</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">animosa signa,</quote> <trans><tr>life-like statues</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:8:9" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 8, 9</bibl></cit>): si nihil esset in eo (animo), nisi id, ut per eum viveremus, i. e. were it mere <hi rend="ital">anima</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:24:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 24, 56</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Singularis est quaedam natura atque vis animi, sejuncta ab his usitatis notisque naturis, i. e. the four material elements,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 27, 66</bibl></cit>: Neque nos corpora sumus. Cum igitur <hi rend="ital">nosce te</hi> dicit, hoc dicit, <hi rend="ital">nosce animum tuum</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 22, 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">In quo igitur loco est (animus)? Credo equidem in capite,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 29, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpora nostra, terreno principiorum genere confecta, ardore animi concalescunt,</quote> <trans><tr>derive their heat from the fiery nature of the soul</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 18, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non valet tantum animus, ut se ipsum ipse videat: at, ut oculus, sic animus, se non videns alia cernit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 27, 67</bibl></cit>: foramina illa (<hi rend="ital">the senses</hi>), quae patent ad animum a corpore, callidissimo artificio natura fabricata est, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 20, 47</bibl>: dum peregre est animus sine corpore velox, <hi rend="ital">independently of the body</hi>, i. e. the mind roaming in thought, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 12, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">discessus animi a corpore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:9:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 9, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 30, 72</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum nihil erit praeter animum,</quote> <trans><tr>when there shall be nothing but the soul</tr>, <tr>when the soul shall be disembodied</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 20, 47</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">animus vacans corpore,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 22, 50</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">animus sine corpore,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 22, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sine mente animoque nequit residere per artus pars ulla animaï,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:398" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 398</bibl></cit> (for the pleonasm here, <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>, II. A. 1.): <cit><quote lang="la">Reliquorum sententiae spem adferunt posse animos, cum e corporibus excesserint in caelum pervenire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:11:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 11, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">permanere animos arbitramur consensu nationum omnium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 16, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pherecydes primus dixit animos esse hominum sempiternos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 16, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quod ni ita se haberet, ut animi immortales essent, haud etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:23:82" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 23, 82</bibl></cit>: immortalitas<cb n="ANIM" />  animorum, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 21, 78</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:11:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 11, 24</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 14, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeternitas animorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 17, 39</bibl></cit>; 1, 22, 50 (for the <number>plur.</number> animorum, in this phrase, cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:23:84" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 23, 84</bibl>); for the atheistic notions about the soul, v. Lucr. bk. iii.—</sense><sense id="n2636.1" n="II" level="1"> In a more restricted sense, the mind as thinking, feeling, willing, <hi rend="ital">the intellect</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the sensibility</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">the will</hi>, acc. to the almost universally received division of the mental powers since the time of Kant (Diog. Laert. 8, 30, says that Pythagoras divided <foreign lang="greek">h( yuxh/</foreign> into <foreign lang="greek">o( nou=s, ai( fre/nes</foreign>, and <foreign lang="greek">o( qumo/s</foreign>; and that man had <foreign lang="greek">o( nou=s</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">o( qumo/s</foreign> in common with other animals, but he alone had <foreign lang="greek">ai( fre/nes</foreign>. Here <foreign lang="greek">o( nou=s</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">o( qumo/s</foreign> must denote <hi rend="ital">the understanding</hi> and <hi rend="ital">the sensibility</hi>, and <foreign lang="greek">ai( fre/nes</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the reason.</hi> Plutarch de Placit. 4, 21, says that the Stoics called the supreme faculty of the mind (<foreign lang="greek">to\ h(gemoniko\n th=s yuxh=s</foreign>) <foreign lang="greek">o( logismo/s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">reason.</hi> Cic. sometimes speaks of a twofold division; as, Est animus in partes tributus duas, quarum altera rationis est particeps, altera expers (i. e. <foreign lang="greek">to\ logistiko/n</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">to\ a)/logon</foreign> of Plato; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 16</bibl>), i. e. <hi rend="ital">the reason</hi> or <hi rend="ital">intellect</hi> and <hi rend="ital">the sensibility</hi>, Tusc. 2, 21, 47; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 28, 101</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 36, 132</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc 4, 5, 10</bibl>; and again of a threefold; as, Plato triplicem finxit animum, cujus principatum, id est rationem in capite sicut in arce posuit, et duas partes (<hi rend="ital">the two</hi> other <hi rend="ital">parts</hi>) ei parere voluit, iram et cupiditatem, quas locis disclusit; iram in pectore, cupiditatem subter praecordia locavit, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the reason</hi> or <hi rend="ital">intellect</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">the sensibility</hi> here resolved into <hi rend="ital">desire</hi> and <hi rend="ital">aversion</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 10, 20</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 39, 124</bibl>. <hi rend="ital">The will</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">h( bou/lhsis</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">voluntas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arbitrium</hi>, seems to have been sometimes merged in <hi rend="ital">the sensibility</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">o( qumo/s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">animus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">animi</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sensus</hi>, and sometimes identified with <hi rend="ital">the intellect</hi> or <hi rend="ital">reason</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">o( nou=s, o( logismo/s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">mens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ratio</hi>). </sense><sense id="n2636.2" n="A. 1." level="1"> The general power of perception and thought, <hi rend="ital">the reason</hi>, <hi rend="ital">intellect</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mind</hi> (syn.: mens, ratio, ingenium), <foreign lang="greek">o( nou=s</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">cogito cum meo animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 3, 2, 13</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 4, 55</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum animis vestris cogitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">recordari cum animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:25:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 25, 70</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and without cum: animo meditari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 4, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,022:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ham. 4, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cogitare volvereque animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:5" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animo cogitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:37:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 37, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">statuere apud animum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proposui in animo meo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi me animus fallit, hi sunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 9, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in dubio est animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 5, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> prol. 1; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum ad se ipsum advocamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:31:75" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 31, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lumen animi, ingenii consiliique tui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:12 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 12 al.</bibl></cit>— <cit><quote lang="la">For the sake of rhet. fulness, animus often has a synonym joined with it: Mens et animus et consilium et sententia civitatis posita est in legibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 146</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnam cui mentem animumque Delius inspirat vates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">complecti animo et cogitatione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:32:117" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 32, 117</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 2, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animis et cogitatione comprehendere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 27, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum omnia ratione animoque lustraris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:17:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 17, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animorum ingeniorumque naturale quoddam quasi pabulum consideratio naturae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 41, 127</bibl></cit>.—Hence the expressions: agitatio animi, attentio, contentio; animi adversio; applicatio animi; judicium, opinio animorum, etc. (v. these vv.); and animum advertere, adjungere, adplicare, adpellere, inducere, etc. (v. these vv.).—</sense><sense id="n2636.3" n="2" level="3"> Of particular faculties of mind, <hi rend="ital">the memory</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam nunc mihi Scripta illa dicta sunt in animo Chrysidis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 5, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">An imprimi, quasi ceram, animum putamus etc. (an idea of Aristotle's),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:25:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 25, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex animo effluere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:74:300" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 74, 300</bibl></cit>: omnia fert aetas, animum quoque; <cit><quote lang="la">... Nunc oblita mihi tot carmina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:9:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 9, 51</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2636.4" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Consciousness</hi> (physically considered) or <hi rend="ital">the vital power</hi>, on which consciousness depends ( = conscientia, q. v. II. A., or anima, q. v. II. E.): <cit><quote lang="la">vae miserae mihi. Animo malest: aquam velim,</quote> <trans><tr>I'm fainting</tr>, <tr>my wits are going</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 5, 1, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">reliquit animus Sextium gravibus acceptis vulneribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Unā eademque viā sanguis animusque sequuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:487" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 487</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animusque reliquit euntem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:459" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 459</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi si timor abstulit omnem Sensum animumque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:177" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 177</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">linqui deinde animo et submitti genu coepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:6:20" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 6, 20</bibl></cit>: repente animo linqui solebat, Suet. <cb n="ANIM" /> <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad recreandos defectos animo puleio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 14, 54, § 152</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2636.5" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The conscience</hi>, in mal. part. (v. conscientia, II. B. 2. b.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum conscius ipse animus se remordet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1135" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1135</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos conscius animus exagitabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 14:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 14, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suae malae cogitationes conscientiaeque animi terrent,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sex. Rosc. 67</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2636.6" n="5" level="3"> In Plaut. very freq., and once also in Cic., meton. for judicium, sententia, <hi rend="ital">opinion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">judgment;</hi> mostly meo quidem animo or meo animo, <hi rend="ital">according to my mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in my opinion</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 3, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">e meo quidem animo aliquanto facias rectius, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 3, 6, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meo quidem animo, hic tibi hodie evenit bonus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 69</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 3, 5, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 4, 2, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">edepol lenones meo animo novisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 4, 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi, ut meus est animus, fieri non posse arbitror,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 5</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">EX MEI ANIMI SENTENTIA,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3665</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex animi tui sententiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:29:108" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 29, 108</bibl></cit>).—</sense><sense id="n2636.7" n="6" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The imagination</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the fancy</hi> (for which Cic. often uses cogitatio, as Ac. 2, 15, 48): <cit><quote lang="la">cerno animo sepultam patriam, miseros atque insepultos acervos civium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 4, 6, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fingere animo jubebat aliquem etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:12:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 12, 41</bibl></cit>: Fingite animis; <cit><quote lang="la">litterae enim sunt cogitationes nostrae, et quae volunt, sic intuentur, ut ea cernimus, quae videmus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:29:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 29, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nihil animo videre poterant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:16:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 16, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2636.8" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The power of feeling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the sensibility</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the heart</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the feelings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affections</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inclinations</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disposition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">passions</hi> (either honorable or base; syn.: sensus, adfectus, pectus, cor), <foreign lang="greek">o( qumo/s</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n2636.9" n="1. a." level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">heart</hi>, <hi rend="ital">soul</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spirit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">feeling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inclination</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affection</hi>, <hi rend="ital">passion</hi>: Medea, animo aegra, amore saevo saucia, Enn. ap. Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 2, 22</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 36</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animo hercle homo suo est miser): tu si animum vicisti potius quam animus te, est quod gaudeas, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 27</bibl></cit>-29: <cit><quote lang="la">harum scelera et lacrumae confictae dolis Redducunt animum aegrotum ad misericordiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quo gemitu conversi animi (sunt),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hoc fletu concussi animi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 498</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">4, 310: animum offendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Lig. 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 33</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:26:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 26, 35</bibl>.—Mens and animus are often conjoined and contrasted, <hi rend="ital">mind and heart</hi> (cf. the Homeric <foreign lang="greek">kata\ fre/na kai\ kata\ qumo/n</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">in mind and heart</hi>): mentem atque animum delectat suum, <hi rend="ital">entertains his mind and delights his heart</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Satin tu sanus mentis aut animi tui?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mala mens, malus animus,</quote> <trans><tr>bad mind</tr>, <tr>bad heart</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 137</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum et mentem meam ipsā cogitatione hominum excellentium conformabam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 6, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nec vero corpori soli subveniendum est, sed menti atque animo multo magis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:11:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 11, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut omnium mentes animosque perturbaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Istuc mens animusque fert,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 14, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Stare Socrates dicitur tamquam quodam recessu mentis atque animi facto a corpore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:2:7" default="NO">15, 2, 7</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">And very rarely with this order inverted: Jam vero animum ipsum mentemque hominis, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:59:147" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 59, 147</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mente animoque nobiscum agunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem nobis animum, quas mentes imprecentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 84</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and sometimes pleon. without such distinction: in primis regina quietum Accipit in Teucros animum mentemque benignam,</quote> <trans><tr>a quiet mind and kindly heart</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:304" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 304</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">pravitas animi atque ingenii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:112:7" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 112, 7</bibl></cit> (for mens et animus, etc., in the sense of <hi rend="ital">thought</hi>, used as a pleonasm, <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">supra</ref></xr>, II. A. 1.): <cit><quote lang="la">Verum animus ubi semel se cupiditate devinxit malā, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus perturbatus et incitatus nec cohibere se potest, nec quo loco vult insistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:18:41" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 18, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum comprimit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 22, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus alius ad alia vitia propensior,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 37, 81</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ad Q. Fr. 1, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed quid ego hic animo lamentor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:6:40" default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Ann. 6, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tremere animo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> ad Q. Fr. 1, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingentes animo concipit iras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:166" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 166</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exsultare animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:6:514" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 514</bibl></cit>.—So often ex animo, <hi rend="ital">from the heart</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from the bottom of one's heart</hi>, <hi rend="ital">deeply</hi>, <hi rend="ital">truly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sincerely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Paulum interesse censes ex animo omnia facias an de industriā?</quote> <trans><tr>from your heart or with some design</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 4, 55</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:1:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 1, 1, 47</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi quod tibi bene ex animo volo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 5, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: verbum <pb n="124" /> <cb n="ANIM" /> ex animo dicere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 95</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sive ex animo id fit sive simulate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:67:168" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 67, 168</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">majore studio magisve ex animo petere non possum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 11, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex animo vereque diligi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex animo dolere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:432" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 432</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (gentes) dederunt terram meam sibi cum gaudio et toto corde et ex animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:36:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 36, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,010:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eph. 6, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1</bibl> Pet. 5, 3.—And with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2636.10" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">verbs</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid illam miseram animi excrucias?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:2:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 2, 76</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 6, 65</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antipho me excruciat animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">discrucior animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 4, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in spe pendebit animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 4, 5</bibl></cit>: juvenemque animi miserata repressit, <hi rend="ital">pitying him in her heart</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">qumw=| file/ousa/ te khdome/nh te</foreign> (Hom.
