Il. 1, 196), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:686" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 686</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2636.11" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">adjj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeger animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:3:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 3, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 58</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">infelix animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:529" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 529</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">felix animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:159" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 159</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">victus animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:491" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 491</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferox animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">promptus animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praestans animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingens animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 69</bibl></cit> (for this <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> v. Ramsh. Gr. p. 323; Key, § 935; Wagner ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:v. 105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. v. 105</bibl>; Draeger, Hist. Synt. I. p. 443).— </sense><sense id="n2636.12" n="b" level="4"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">disposition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">character</hi> (so, often ingenium): nimis paene animo es Molli, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:21:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 21, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animo audaci proripit sese,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0116,001:Trag. Rel. p. 109" default="NO"><author>Pac.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 109</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">petulans protervo, iracundo animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 3, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi te vidi animo esse omisso (omisso = neglegenti, Don.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 2, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2</bibl>. 17 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">promptus animus vester,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Cor. 9, 2</bibl></cit>: animis estis simplicibus et mansuetis nimium creditis unicuique, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">eorum animi molles et aetate fluxi dolis haud difficulter capiebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 14:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 14, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hecabe, Non oblita animorum, annorum oblita suorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:550" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 550</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nihil est tam angusti animi tamque parvi, quam amare divitias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:20:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 20, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sordidus atque animi parvi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:25:3" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 25, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Drusus animi fluxioris erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:52" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 52</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2636.13" n="2" level="3"> In particular, some one specific emotion, inclination, or passion (honorable or base; in this signif., in the poets and prose writers, very freq. in the <number>plur.</number>). —</sense><sense id="n2636.14" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Courage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spirit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ibi nostris animus additus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 94</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 2, 1, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">deficiens animo maesto cum corde jacebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1232" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1232</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtute atque animo resistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 2, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fac animo magno fortique sis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 14</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cassio animus accessit, et Parthis timor injectus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:20:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 20, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nostris animus augetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi in dies magis animus accenditur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 20:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 20, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:29" default="NO" valid="yes">44, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nunc demum redit animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellica Pallas adest, Datque animos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pares annis animisque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:7:558" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 558</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cecidere illis animique manusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:7:347" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 347</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">tela viris animusque cadunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:225" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 3, 225</bibl></cit>) et saep.—Hence, bono animo esse or uti, <hi rend="ital">to be of good courage</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:5:5" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 5, 5</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Am.</hi> Bono animo es. <hi rend="ital">So.</hi> Scin quam bono animo sim? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:22:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 22, 39</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">In re malā animo si bono utare, adjuvat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 2, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bono animo fac sis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin tu animo bono es,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quare bono animo es,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 18</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:11:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 11, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:18:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 18, 25</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">so also, satis animi,</quote> <trans><tr>sufficient courage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:559" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 559</bibl></cit>.—Also for <hi rend="ital">hope</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnus mihi animus est, hodiernum diem initium libertatis fore,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Agr, 30</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of the violent, stormy motion of the winds of Æolus: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeolus mollitque animos et temperat iras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 57</bibl></cit>.—Of a top: <cit><quote lang="la">dant animos plagae,</quote> <trans><tr>give it new force</tr>, <tr>quicker motion</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:383" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 383</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Of spirit in discourse: in Asinio Pollione et consilii et animi satis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:113" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 113</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2636.15" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Haughtiness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arrogance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pride</hi>: quae civitas est in Asiā, quae unius tribuni militum animos ac spiritus capere possit? <hi rend="ital">can bear the arrogance and pride</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:22:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 22, 66</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam insolentiam norātis hominis: norātis animos ejus ac spiritus tribunicios,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:39:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 39, 109</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:11 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 11 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:8:3" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 8, 3</bibl> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quia paululum vobis accessit pecuniae, Sublati animi sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:5:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 5, 56</bibl></cit>).—</sense><sense id="n2636.16" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Violent passion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vehemence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wrath</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum vincere, iracundiam cohibere, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,032:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Marcell. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum rege, qui nisi paret Imperat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui dominatur animo suo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:16:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 16, 32</bibl></cit>.—So often in <number>plur.</number>; cf <foreign lang="greek">oi( qumoi/</foreign>: ego <cb n="ANIM" /> meos animos violentos meamque iram ex pectore jam promam, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 43</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vince animos iramque tuam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:3:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 3, 85</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:583" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 8, 583</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:5:12" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 5, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Parce tuis animis, vita, nocere tibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:5:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sic longius aevum Destruit ingentes animos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">coëunt sine more, sine arte, Tantum animis irāque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:11:525 al" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 11, 525 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2636.17" n="d" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Moderation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">patience</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calmness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contentedness</hi>, in the phrase aequus animus, <hi rend="ital">an even mind</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si est animus aequos tibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 71</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:50:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 50, 145</bibl>; and often in the <case>abl.</case>, aequo animo, <hi rend="ital">with even mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">patiently</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">aequo animo ferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 3, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:39:93" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 39, 93</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:23:84" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 23, 84</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion. 6, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 39</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequo animo esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:21:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 21, 7</bibl></cit>; ib. Judith, 7, 23: Aequo animo est? <hi rend="ital">of merry heart</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">eu)qumei=</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,020:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Jac. 5, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animis aequis remittere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequiore animo successorem opperiri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:25" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud aequioribus animis audire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 22</bibl></cit>: sapientissimus quisque aequissimo animo moritur; stultissimus iniquissimo. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:23:83" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 23, 83</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:45:109" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 45, 109</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 3, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:56" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 56</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">iniquo animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag. Rel. p. 150" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 150</bibl></cit> Rib.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 2, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:66" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 66</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2636.18" n="e" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Agreeable feeling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pleasure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">delight</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cubat amans animo obsequens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 134</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">indulgent animis, et nulla quid utile cura est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:566" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 566</bibl></cit>; so, esp. freq.: animi causā (in Plaut. once animi gratiā), <hi rend="ital">for the sake of amusement</hi>, <hi rend="ital">diversion</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">haec (animalia) alunt animi voluptatisque causā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 12</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">Post animi causā mihi navem faciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 2, 27</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:1:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 43</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberare fidicinam animi gratiā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui illud animi causā fecerit, hunc praedae causā quid facturum putabis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:7:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 7, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habet animi causā rus amoenum et suburbanum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 46</bibl></cit> Matth.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> § 134, and Madv. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:17:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 17, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Romanos in illis munitionibus animine causā cotidie exerceri putatis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 77</bibl></cit>; Plin. praef. 17 Sill.—</sense><sense id="n2636.19" n="f" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Disposition toward any one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc animo in nos esse debebis, ut etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meus animus erit in te semper, quem tu esse vis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 18</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui, quo animo inter nos simus, ignorant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 6</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 15</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">5, 2: In quo in primis quo quisque animo, studio, benevolentiā fecerit, ponderandum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:15:49" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 15, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod (Allobroges) nondum bono animo in populum Romanum viderentur,</quote> <trans><tr>to be well disposed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—In the pregn. signif. of <hi rend="ital">kind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">friendly feeling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affection</hi>, <hi rend="ital">kindness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">liberality</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum fidemque praetorianorum erga se expertus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nec non aurumque animusque Latino est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 23</bibl></cit>.—Hence, meton., of a person who is loved, <hi rend="ital">my heart</hi>, <hi rend="ital">my soul</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">salve, anime mi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">da, meus ocellus, mea rosa, mi anime, da, mea voluptas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 3, 3, 74</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 2, 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 1, 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 4, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 1, 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 8, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 8, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 15</bibl> et saep. —</sense><sense id="n2636.20" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The power of willing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the will</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inclination</hi>, <hi rend="ital">desire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">purpose</hi>, <hi rend="ital">design</hi>, <hi rend="ital">intention</hi> (syn.: voluntas, arbitrium, mens, consilium, propositum), <foreign lang="greek">h( bou/lhsis</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui rem publicam animo certo adjuverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag Rel. p. 182" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag Rel. p. 182</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">pro inperio tuo meum animum tibi servitutem servire aequom censui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ex animique voluntate id procedere primum,</quote> <trans><tr>goes forth at first from the inclination of the soul</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:270" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 270</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">pro animi mei voluntate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 20, 8</bibl></cit> (v. Manut. ad h.l.): <cit><quote lang="la">teneo, quid animi vostri super hac re siet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 1, 187</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nam si semel tuom animum ille intellexerit, Prius proditurum te etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Prius quam tuom ut sese habeat animum ad nuptias perspexerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 2, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sin aliter animus voster est, ego etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:4:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 3, 4, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid mi istaec narras? an quia non audisti, de hac re animus meus ut sit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 5, 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui ab auro gazāque regiā manus, oculos, animum cohibere possit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:chapter=66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">istum exheredare in animo habebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:18:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 18, 52</bibl></cit>: nobis crat in animo Ciceronem ad Caesarem mittere, <hi rend="ital">we had it in mind to send</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:14:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 14, 11</bibl>; Serv. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> ib. 4, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hostes in foro constiterunt, hoc animo, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insurrexerunt uno animo in Paulum,</quote> <trans><tr>with one mind</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:18:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 18, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">19, 29</bibl>: persequi<cb n="ANIU" />  Jugurtham animus ardebat, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 39:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 39, 5</bibl> Gerlach (others, <hi rend="ital">animo</hi>, as Dietsch); so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:de Rep. Ord. 1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Rep. Ord. 1, 8</bibl>: in nova fert animus mutatas dicere formas, <hi rend="ital">my mind inclines to tell of</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 1</bibl>.—Hence, est animus alicui, with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to have a mind for</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">to aim at</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">omnibus unum Opprimere est animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sacra Jovi Stygio perficere est animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:639" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 639</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Fuerat animus conjuratis corpus occisi in Tiberim trahere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:82" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 82 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oth. 6</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 56</bibl>.—So, aliquid alicui in animo est, with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 3</bibl>.—So, inducere in animum <hi rend="ital">or</hi> animum, <hi rend="ital">to resolve upon doing something;</hi> v. induco.—</sense><sense id="n2636.21" n="D" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of the principle of life and activity in irrational objects, as in Engl. the word mind is used. </sense><sense id="n2636.22" n="1" level="3"> Of brutes: <cit><quote lang="la">in bestiis, quarum animi sunt rationis expertes,</quote> <trans><tr>whose minds</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:33:80" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 33, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sunt bestiae, in quibus etiam animorum aliquā ex parte motus quosdam videmus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:14:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 14, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut non inscite illud dictum videatur in sue, animum illi pecudi datum pro sale, ne putisceret,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 13, 38</bibl></cit>, ubi v. Madv.: <cit><quote lang="la">(apes Ingentes animos angusto in pectore versant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Illiusque animos, qui multos perdidit unus, Sumite serpentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:544" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 544</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum pecudes pro regionis caelique statu et habitum corporis et ingenium animi et pili colorem gerant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:1:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Umbria (boves progenerat) vastos nec minus probabiles animis quam corporibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 1, 2</bibl></cit> si equum ipsum nudum et solum corpus ejus et animum contemplamur, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> de Deo Socr. 23</bibl> (so sometimes mens: <cit><quote lang="la">iniquae mentis asellus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 20</bibl></cit>).—</sense><sense id="n2636.23" n="2" level="3"> Of plants: <cit><quote lang="la">haec quoque Exuerint silvestrem animum, i. e. naturam, ingenium,</quote> <trans><tr>their wild nature</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 51</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2636.24" n="III" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> Of God or the gods, as we say, <hi rend="ital">the Divine Mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Mind of God</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">certe et deum ipsum et divinum animum corpore liberatum cogitatione complecti possumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:22:51" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 22, 51</bibl></cit> (so mens, of God, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 22, 66</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 41, 126</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">Tantaene animis caelestibus irae?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anio: <entryFree id="n2637" type="main" key="A^ni^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭo</orth>, <itype>ēnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ani/wn</foreign>, Strab., <foreign lang="greek">*)ani/hs</foreign>, Plut. (the orig. form was <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭen</orth>: non minus quam XV. milia Anien abest, Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 684</bibl> P.; also in Stat.: praeceps Anien, S. 1, 5, 25; 1, 3, 20. Still Enn., acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 7, 683</bibl>, used the form Anio, ōnis, analogous to the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*)ani/wn</foreign>; cf. also Anionis in Front. Aquaed. § 92; <sense id="n2637.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">and, ANIONIS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3203</bibl></cit>; and thus, during the whole class. per., Anio remained the principal form of the <case>nom.</case>, while the remaining cases of Anien were retained; only Aug. and post-Aug. poets, e. g. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:7:86" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 7, 86</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:3:70" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 3, 70</bibl>, have as an access. form. <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭēnus</orth>, i; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 8, 72</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 684</bibl> P; Phoc. Ars, p. 1691 P.; Schne<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gram. II. 148</bibl>; Rudd. I. p. 60; Neue, Formenl. I. pp. 163, 187), <hi rend="ital">the classic tributary stream of the Tiber</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which</hi>, <hi rend="ital">taking its rise in the Apennines</hi>, <hi rend="ital">passes along the southern Sabine country</hi>, <hi rend="ital">separating it from Latium; and at Tibur</hi>, <hi rend="ital">beside its cataract</hi> (hence, praeceps Anio, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 7, 13</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">it presents the most charming natural beauties;</hi> now <hi rend="ital">Teverone</hi>, Cic. Corn. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 684</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">Anio spumifer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:7:81" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 7, 81</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:329" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 329</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:109 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 12, 17, § 109 al.</bibl> The waters of the upper Anio are very pure, and in ancient times aqueducts conveyed them to Rome. The first, called Anio Vetus, was constructed B. C. 271, by M'. Curius Dentatus and Fulvius Flaccus; it began twenty miles from Rome, but wound about for fortythree miles. The second, built by the emperor Claudius, and known as Anio Novus, took up the stream forty-two miles from Rome, and was about sixty miles in length, preserving the highest level of all the aqueducts of Rome, cf. Front. Aquaed. §§ 6, 13, 15; Nibby, Dintorni, I. pp. 156-160; cf. Mann. Ital. 1, 517; Müll. Roms Camp. 1, 157; 1, 229; 1, 241; 1, 306 al.</sense></entryFree>
anisocycla: <entryFree id="n2638" type="greek" key="a^ni_so^cy_^cla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănīsŏcȳ^cla</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)niso/kukla</foreign> (with unequal rings or circles), <sense id="n2638.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">screws</hi> or <hi rend="ital">elastic springs.</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anisum: <entryFree id="n2639" type="greek" key="a^ni_sum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănīsum</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ane-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/nison</foreign>, <sense id="n2639.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">anise</hi>: Pimpinella anisum, Linn.: Et anesum adversum scorpiones ex vino habetur ... ob has causas quidam anicetum id vocavere, i. e. <foreign lang="greek">a)ni/khton</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">all powerful</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:185 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 17, 72, § 185 sq.</bibl> Jan.</sense></entryFree>
anius: <entryFree id="n2640" type="main" key="A^ni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2640.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a king and priest at Delos</hi>,<pb n="125" /> <cb n="ANNA" />  <hi rend="ital">who hospitably entertained Æneas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 80</bibl>, ubi, v. Serv.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:632" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 632</bibl>; cf. Lycophr. Cassandr. 570.</sense></entryFree>
anna: <entryFree id="n2641" type="main" key="Anna" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <foreign /> (cf. Gesen. Gesch. Hebr. Spr. p. 228), <sense id="n2641.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the sister of Dido</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 9</bibl> et saep.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:7:191" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 7, 191</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:55 al" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 55 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
annaperenna: <entryFree id="n2642" type="main" key="Anna Perenna" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anna Perenna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2642.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an old Italian goddess</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the protector</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bestower of the returning year</hi> (acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 12</bibl>, offerings were made to her, ut <hi rend="ital">annare perennareque</hi> commode liceat, and hence her name); cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> II. 1847</bibl>; II. p. 412; in later times she was identified with 1. Anna; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:654" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 654</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:50 sq" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 50 sq.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
annalis: <entryFree id="n2643" type="main" key="anna_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>annus</etym>. <sense id="n2643.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Continuing a year</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annual</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus, cursus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:27:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 27, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:14:2:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 14, 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:17:6" default="NO">38, 17, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2643.1" n="II. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Relating to the year</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the age</hi>: Lex Villia Annalis, <hi rend="ital">the law passed</hi> B. C. 180 <hi rend="ital">by</hi> L. Villius, <hi rend="ital">which determined the age necessary for election to an office of state</hi> (for the quæstorship, 31; for the office of ædile, 37; for the praetorship, 40; <cit><quote lang="la">and for the consulship, 43 years): legibus annalibus grandiorem aetatem ad consulatum constituebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 5, 17</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">eo anno (573 A. U. C.) rogatio primum lata est ab L. Villio tribuno plebis, quot annos nati quemque magistratum peterent caperentque. Inde cognomen familiae inditum, ut annales appellarentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 44</bibl></cit>; cf. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 65</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2643.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">annālis</orth>, <itype>is</itype> (<case>abl.</case> reg. annali, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:15:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 15, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 13, 1</bibl>; but annalei, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 1, 17, p. 97</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">annale,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0803,001:ad Cic. Pis. 22:52" default="NO"><author>Ascon.</author> ad Cic. Pis. 22, 52</bibl></cit>; v. Neue, Formenl. I. p. 224), <hi rend="ital">subst. m.</hi> (sc. liber), most freq. in <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">an-nāles</orth>, <itype>ium</itype> (sc. libri), <hi rend="ital">an historical work</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in which the occurrences of the year are chronologically recorded</hi>, <hi rend="ital">chronicles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annals</hi> (diff. from <hi rend="ital">historia</hi>, a philosophical narration. following the internal relation of events, Ver. Fl. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:18" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 18</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 20</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n2643.3" n="1" level="3"> Spec., from the most ancient per. down to the time of the Gracchi, when a literature had been formed, each pontifex maximus wrote down the occurrences of his year on tablets, which were hung up in his dwelling for the information of the public. Such tablets, accordingly, received the name of Annales Maximi (not to be confounded with the <hi rend="ital">Libri Pontificales</hi> sive <hi rend="ital">Pontificii</hi>, which contained instructions and liturgies for the holy rites). See the class. passages, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:12:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 12, 51</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 16</bibl>; Fest. s. v. maximi, and cf. Creuz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:30" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 2</bibl>; Niebuhr, Rom. Hist. 1, 277 sq. From these sources the Rom. histt. drew, and hence called their works, in gen., Annales. The most renowned among the annalists of the ancient period are Q. Fabius Pictor, M. Porcius Cato, and L. Calpurnius Piso (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:12:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 12, 51</bibl>); in the time of the emperors, Tacitus named one of his hist. works Annales, since in it the history of Rome, from the death of Aug. until the time of Nero, was given acc. to the <hi rend="ital">annual</hi> succession of events; cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 255 sq.; 301 sq.; 313 sq.; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 333, 1.—Annalis in <number>sing.</number>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 13, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 28, 29, § 101</bibl>.—<pos>Adj.</pos>, with <hi rend="ital">liber</hi>, Ver. Fl. in the above-cited passage, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:68" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 68</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2643.4" n="2" level="3"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">records</hi>, <hi rend="ital">archives</hi>, <hi rend="ital">history</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">carminibus antiquis, quod unum apud illos memoriae et annalium genus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">annalibus traditum (est) coram rege,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,019:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Esth. 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">annales priorum temporum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 6, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2643.5" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">annālia</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a festival observed at the beginning of the year</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 116, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
annarius: <entryFree id="n2644" type="main" key="anna_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2644.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">relating to the appointed year</hi>: annaria lex dicebatur ab antiquis, quā finiuntur anni magistratus capiendi, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=27" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 27</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">lex,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Com. 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 2, p. 91</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
annascor: <entryFree id="n2645" type="main" key="annascor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annascor</orth>, v. agnascor.</entryFree>
annato: <entryFree id="n2646" type="main" key="anna^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-năto</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <sense id="n2646.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To swim to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ei insulae crocodili non adnatant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 25, 38, § 93</bibl></cit>; Jan here reads <hi rend="ital">adnant;</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:10:610" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 10, 610</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad manum hominis adnatare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 29, 46, § 87</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:38" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 10, 12, § 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2646.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To swim along by</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by the side of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">comes lateri adnatat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Agam. 452" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Agam. 452</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
annavigo: <entryFree id="n2647" type="main" key="anna_vi^go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-nāvĭgo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n2647.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to sail to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to come to by ship.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2647.1" n="a" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">tres (pyramides) sane conspicuae undique adnavigantibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:12:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 12, 16</bibl></cit>, <cb n="ANNI" /> § 76.—</sense><sense id="n2647.2" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">quo</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo cum adnavigāsset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anne: <entryFree id="n2648" type="main" key="anne"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anne</orth>, v. 1. an, I. F.</entryFree>
annecto: <entryFree id="n2649" type="main" key="annecto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-necto</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>nexui, nexum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n2649.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to tie</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bind to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to connect</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annex.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2649.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: (animum) corporibus nostris, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:688" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 688</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">funiculus scapham adnexam trahebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:51" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad linguam stomachus adnectitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 54</bibl></cit>; Sall. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 11, 770</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adnexa (ratis) erat vinculis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">continenti adnexuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 31, § 117</bibl></cit>, where Jan reads <hi rend="ital">adjecit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">epistulae adnexae pedibus columbarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 37, 53, § 110</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">remedia corporibus aegrorum,</quote> <trans><tr>to apply</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:2:5" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 2, 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2649.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">rebus praesentibus adnectit futuras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquod membrum adnexum orationi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 18</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
annellus: <entryFree id="n2650" type="main" key="annellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annellus</orth>, v. anellus.</entryFree>
annexio: <entryFree id="n2651" type="hapax" key="annexi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annexĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>annecto</etym>, <sense id="n2651.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tying</hi> or <hi rend="ital">binding to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a connecting</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> Mart. 10, 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
annexus: <entryFree id="n2652" type="main" key="annexus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annexus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of annecto.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2653" type="hapax" key="annexus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annexus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>annecto</etym>, <sense id="n2653.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tying</hi> or <hi rend="ital">binding to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a connection</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cremona annexu connubiisque gentium floruit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 34</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
annianus: <entryFree id="n2654" type="main" key="Anni^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Annĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <sense id="n2654.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Annius</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Annia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 46</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2654.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a Roman poet under the emperors Antonine and Adrian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:8" default="NO">20, 8</bibl>; cf. Bähr, Röm. Gesch. 71 and 194; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 349, 3.</sense></entryFree>
annibal: <entryFree id="n2655" type="main" key="Anni^bal"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Annĭbal</orth>, v. Hannibal.</entryFree>
annicerii: <entryFree id="n2656" type="main" key="Anni^ce^ri_i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Annĭcĕrīi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)annike/reioi</foreign>, <sense id="n2656.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a philosophical sect of Cyrene</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so called from its founder Anniceris</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:33:116" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 33, 116</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
annicto: <entryFree id="n2657" type="main" key="annicto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-nicto</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), āre. <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n2657.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to wink with the eyes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to wink</hi> or <hi rend="ital">blink to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">at</hi>: alii adnutat, alii adnictat, Naev. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=29" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 29</bibl> Müll. (Com. Rel. p. 19 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
anniculus: <entryFree id="n2658" type="main" key="anni^cu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annĭcŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>annus</etym>, <sense id="n2658.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a year old</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of a year</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">a yearling</hi> (not in Cic.; <cit><quote lang="la">freq. in Vulg.): nuces,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 17, 2</bibl></cit> Schneid.: <cit><quote lang="la">taurus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:5:12" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vituli,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Micah, 6, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agnus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Ex. 12, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ovis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:14:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Lev. 14, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">capra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 15, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:65" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 65</bibl></cit>: virgo vix annicula, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:19:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 19, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:9:2 al" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 9, 2 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
annifer: <entryFree id="n2659" type="main" key="anni^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annĭfer</orth>, <itype>fera, ferum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>annus-fero</etym> (only in Plin. H. N.). <sense id="n2659.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Bearing fruit the whole year</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Citreae et junipirus et ilex anniferae habentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 26, 44, § 107</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2659.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Producing annually a new stalk</hi> (in Theophrast. <foreign lang="greek">e)peteio/kaula</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 7, 36, § 121</bibl>, where Jan reads <hi rend="ital">seminifer.</hi></sense></entryFree>
annihilo: <entryFree id="n2660" type="main" key="anni^hi^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-nĭhĭlo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n2660.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bring to nothing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to annihilate;</hi> introd. by Jerome: nullificāsti seu adnihilāsti vel adnullāsti, Hier Ep. 135 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
annisus: <entryFree id="n2661" type="main" key="anni_sus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annīsus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of annitor</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2662" type="hapax" key="anni_sus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annīsus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>annitor</etym>, <sense id="n2662.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a striving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exertion</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut alieno adjuventur adnisu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Ep. 5:74" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> Ep. 5, 74</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
annitor: <entryFree id="n2663" type="main" key="anni_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-nītor</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>nīsus or nixus, 3</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <sense id="n2663.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to press upon</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to lean upon;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <case>dat.</case> (most freq. after the commencement of the Aug. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">natura ad aliquod tamquam adminiculum adnititur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:23:88" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 23, 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hasta ingenti adnixa columnae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stant longis adnixi hastis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 229</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Latona oleae adnisa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 61</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2663.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to take pains about</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">to exert one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strive;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ne.</hi> or a gerund with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> (mostly prose). </sense><sense id="n2663.2" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo mihi acrius adnitendum est, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 85:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 85, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omni ope adnisi sunt, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:58" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 53, 54, § 186</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omni ope adniti, ne quis e plebe, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:25" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 25 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2663.3" n="(b)" level="5"> Ad ea patranda omnis civitas summo studio adnitebatur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 43:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 43, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 14</bibl>.—Other constructions: </sense><sense id="n2663.4" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">de</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi Bibulus adniteretur de triumpho,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 25</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2663.5" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">pro</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">patres non temere pro ullo aeque adnisi sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 61</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">acc. of pron.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 18</bibl>.—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adnitentibus retinere morem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 8</bibl>.—（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">adnitente Crasso,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 19:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 19, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 85:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 85, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 8</bibl>.!*? <orth extent="full" lang="la">adnītendus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, in <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi> signif.: <cit><quote lang="la">si in concordiā adnitendā (i. e. procurandā),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:12:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 12, 5</bibl></cit>. <cb n="ANNO" /></sense></entryFree>
annius: <entryFree id="n2664" type="main" key="Anni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Annĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2664.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens, e. g. T. Annius Milo, T. Annius Cimber, P. Annius Asellus al.—Hence, Annianus, v. Annianus, I.</sense></entryFree>
anniversarie: <entryFree id="n2665" type="main" key="anni^versa_ri^e_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annĭversārĭē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. anniversarius.</entryFree>
anniversarius: <entryFree id="n2666" type="main" key="anni^versa_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annĭversārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>annusverto</etym>, <sense id="n2666.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that returns</hi>, <hi rend="ital">happens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is used</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">every year</hi>, <hi rend="ital">returning</hi> or <hi rend="ital">renewed annually</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annual</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yearly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ecce solemnitas Domini est in Silo anniversaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:21:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jud. 21, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">festi dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 48 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(caeli) vicissitudines,</quote> <trans><tr>the changes of the seasons of the year</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:38:97" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 38, 97</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:16:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 16, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">arma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 45</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">hostes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:12" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">valetudines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:81" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pervigilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:4 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 4 al.</bibl></cit>—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">annĭversārĭē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">annually</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 118" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 118 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
annixus: <entryFree id="n2667" type="main" key="annixus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annixus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of annitor.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2668" type="main" key="annixus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annixus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, v. 2. annisus.</entryFree>
anno: <entryFree id="n2669" type="main" key="anno1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-no</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <sense id="n2669.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To swim to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">along;</hi> constr. with the <case>dat.</case>, <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, or <case>acc.</case> </sense><sense id="n2669.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:358" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 358</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ei insulae crocodili non adnant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 25, 38, § 93</bibl></cit> Jan.—</sense><sense id="n2669.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad litus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:8:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 8, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2669.3" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pauci milites, qui naves adnare possent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 44</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: plures adnabunt thynni, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 44</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2669.4" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod ubique gentium est, ad eam urbem posset adnare,</quote> <trans><tr>come to</tr>, <tr>approach</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 4</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n2669.5" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To swim with</hi> or <hi rend="ital">along with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedites adnantes equis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 29</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2670" type="hapax" key="anno2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anno</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>annus</etym>, <sense id="n2670.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to pass</hi> or <hi rend="ital">live through a year</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 12</bibl>; cf. Anna.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n2671" type="main" key="Anno3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anno</orth>, v. Hanno.</entryFree>
annodo: <entryFree id="n2672" type="main" key="anno_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-nōdo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n2672.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to cut off knots</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to cut away suckers</hi> or <hi rend="ital">shoots of the vine</hi>, in the lang. of gardening and the vintage, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:22:4" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 22, 4</bibl> Schneid.; for which, as also in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:24:10 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 24, 10 al.</bibl>, other edd. have <hi rend="ital">abnodo.</hi></sense></entryFree>
annominatio: <entryFree id="n2673" type="main" key="anno_mi^na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annōmĭnātĭo</orth>, v. agnominatio.</entryFree>
annon: <entryFree id="n2674" type="main" key="annon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annon</orth>, v. 1. an. I. E.</entryFree>
annona: <entryFree id="n2675" type="main" key="anno_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annōna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>from annus, as pomona from pomum</etym>. <sense id="n2675.0" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">the yearly produce</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the annual income of natural products</hi>, in the widest sense (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cibaria annua,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 60</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">vectigal novum ex salariā annonā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lactis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:17:13" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 17, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">musti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:21:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 21, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:3:10" default="NO">3, 3, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2675.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n2675.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Means of subsistence</hi>, and, for the most part, <hi rend="ital">corn</hi> or <hi rend="ital">grain</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">annona nisi in calamitate pretium non habet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 98</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vilitas annonae ex summā inopiā et caritate rei frumentariae consecuta est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:15:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 15, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">uberrimus ager ad varietates annonae horreum populi Romani fore videbatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clausis annonae subsidiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 48 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">provincia annonae fecunda,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 11</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:18" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">annonae curam agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 18</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">praebebant annonam regi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 4, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,014:25:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 4 Reg. 25, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:1:5 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Dan. 1, 5 al.</bibl>—Sometimes contrasted with frumentum, as provisions in gen.: copia frumenti et annona tolerabilis rerum aliarum, <hi rend="ital">a supply</hi>, Liv 35, 44.—</sense><sense id="n2675.3" n="B. 1." level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the price of grain</hi> or <hi rend="ital">other food</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quom cara annona sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 1, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 1, 3, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 4, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 27 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">annona est gravis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:4:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 4, 2, 53</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:25" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">incendere annonam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:2:16" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam ad denarios quinquaginta in singulos modios annona pervenerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil mutavit annona,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 12</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">annona vetus): annona acris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gravitas annonae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in annonae difficultatibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:41" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">annona macelli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 34</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2675.4" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the prices</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the market</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Qui homines probi essent, esset īs annona vilior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 140</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vilis amicorum est annona, bonis ubi quid deest,</quote> <trans><tr>cheap indeed is the market of friendship</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 12, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">his opibus numquam cara est annona veneni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:9:100" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 9, 100</bibl></cit>.—Hence sometimes, </sense><sense id="n2675.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Dearness</hi>: cena hac annonā est sine sacris hereditas, <hi rend="ital">at the present</hi> (i. e. high) <hi rend="ital">market-price</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at the present dear rate</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 83</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob annonae causam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2675.6" n="D" level="2"> In milit. lang., <hi rend="ital">provisions</hi>, <hi rend="ital">supplies</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">necessitas annonam pariter et arma portandi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">annona decem et septem dierum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 17, 9</bibl></cit>.—Hence, meton., <hi rend="ital">the loaves of bread them selves</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rations</hi> (in this sense only in the <number>plur.</number>): ceteri annonas binas aut ternas accipiebant,<pb n="126" /> <cb n="ANNU" />  <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Alex. Sev. 42</bibl>; cf. Cod. Th. 7,5.—</sense><sense id="n2675.7" n="E" level="2"> Personified, <hi rend="ital">the goddess of the yearly produce</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ANNONAE SANCTAE AELIVS VITALIO, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1810</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
annonarius: <entryFree id="n2676" type="main" key="anno_na_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annōnārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>annona</etym>, <sense id="n2676.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of or pertaining to provisions</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">frumentum, ceteraeque annonariae species,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:49:14:46" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 49, 14, 46</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
annonor: <entryFree id="n2677" type="hapax" key="anno_nor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annōnor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2677.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to collect provisions</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> Gord. 29</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
annositas: <entryFree id="n2678" type="main" key="anno_si^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annōsĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>annosus</etym>, <sense id="n2678.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fulness of years</hi>, <hi rend="ital">old age</hi> (post-class.), Cod. Th. 12, 1, 113; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 251" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 251</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
annosus: <entryFree id="n2679" type="main" key="anno_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>annus</etym>, <sense id="n2679.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of many years</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aged</hi>, <hi rend="ital">old</hi> (a favorite word of the Aug. poets and post-Aug. prose writers): <cit><quote lang="la">anus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:571" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 571</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vetustas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:2:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 5, 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">merum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:6:58" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 6, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bracchia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:282" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 282</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">robur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 441</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ornus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 766</bibl></cit> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">cornix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:17:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 17, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">palatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:274" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 3, 274</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">volumina vatum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 26</bibl></cit> (not elsewhere): <cit><quote lang="la">gens, quos Hyperboreos appellavere, annoso degit aevo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 26, § 89</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:2" default="NO" valid="yes">24, 1, 1, § 2</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 1:7" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 1, 7</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 3:1" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 3, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> al.</sense></entryFree>
annotamentum: <entryFree id="n2680" type="main" key="anno^ta_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annŏtāmentum</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>annoto</etym>, <sense id="n2680.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a remark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annotation</hi> (perh. only in Gell.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:7:18" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 7, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:17:2" default="NO">1, 17, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
annotatio: <entryFree id="n2681" type="main" key="anno^ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annŏtātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2681.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a noting down in writing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a remark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annotation</hi> (post-Aug.). </sense><sense id="n2681.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">a te librum meum cum adnotationibus tuis exspecto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 20</bibl></cit>; Gell. praef.—</sense><sense id="n2681.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n2681.3" n="A" level="2"> In the jurists, <hi rend="ital">the registering of a person among the accused</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:17:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 17, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2681.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A rescript of the emperor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">signed with his own hand</hi>, Cod. Th. Fragm. 1, 2, 1.</sense></entryFree>
annotatiuncula: <entryFree id="n2682" type="main" key="anno^ta_ti^uncu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annŏtātĭuncŭla</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>annotatio</etym>, <sense id="n2682.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a brief annotation</hi> (only in Gell.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:7:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 7, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:17:21" default="NO">19, 17, 21</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
annotator: <entryFree id="n2683" type="main" key="anno^ta_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annŏtātor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>annoto</etym>. <sense id="n2683.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An observer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">remarker</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">Non ante medium diem distentus solitariā cenā spectator adnotatorque convivis tuis immines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:49" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 49</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2683.1" n="II" level="1"> In the jurists, <hi rend="ital">the controller of the annual income</hi>, Cod. Th. 12, 6, 3.</sense></entryFree>
annotatus: <entryFree id="n2684" type="hapax" key="anno^ta_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">annŏtātus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2684.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a remark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mention</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mortes dignae adnotatu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:9:12:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 9, 12, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
